products. He has helped clients such as Weber, 3M, Shure & Pyrex define
opportunity spaces & solutions. Previously a senior designer at Radius
Product Development in Chicago, he led & collaborated with teams of
engineers & other designers to take concepts to market for numerous
well-known companies.
@damonite1

Jess Seilheimer, Marketing – 14+ yrs marketing and advertising, strategic planning, product and business development experience within CPG, Retail, health & wellness, technology and pharmaceutical verticals
column2: US & Global. Most recently, Jess was the SVP Digital Strategy & Planning at Havas-- where she created and led a digital strategy practice across creative, user experience, account, media and analytics. She a guest lecturer at Columbia Business School and has been published in Alleywatch, eConsultancy and Medical Marketing & Media. @jaeselle

column1: Anselm Hook, Developer – As a
maker he has over 20 years of technical leadership experience and is most
interested in helping people ""see through walls"". He served as an
Augmented Reality researcher at Xerox Parc, and has built products for
Electronic Arts, Dekko, Waze, Math Engine and Ning. @anselm

Our co-founder Mark had the idea for a smart carbon monoxide detector after Hurricane Sandy. His grandmother lives in what was the evacuation zone. When disaster struck, she was left heating her home with her gas stove for weeks, spewing dangerous amounts of carbon monoxide. His goal became to create something that would call her landline phone and walk her through the problem in her native Russian and also send him a push notification to give a heads up that his grandma was in trouble. Looking at existing products, he saw an opportunity to create something that didn't exist.

Instead of simply building a better carbon monoxide detector or smoke alarm, we redesigned the device from the ground up. Existing products already sense what’s in the air, they just don't go far enough. Why not monitor for both emergency and her overall health every day? Thus, Birdi was hatched.
The smart home
is an emerging sector that's growing fast. We're excited to interact with the other products in your home. Here's how we differentiate ourselves:
PURCHASING & SETUP
BUYING & SHIPPING
USABILITY
HEALTH & SAFETY
PRIVACY & SECURITY
TECHNICAL
OTHER QUESTIONS
TRANSLATIONS
Is Birdi really safe?
We can and will only ship once we adhere to the
proper certification standards (UL 217, UL 2034, CE). But these are the bare
minimum. We’re going above and beyond to make sure that Birdi is even better
than what’s out there. While many alarms only alert once detecting dangerous
levels, we show you prolonged exposure to fumes over time and alert you when
that becomes just as dangerous.
How many Birdi devices do I need in my home?
The national fire alarm code states that
you need one in your bedrooms, hallway, kitchen, living room and basement. Birdi is wirelessly interconnected (a multiple station device) so if there’s an
emergency in the kitchen, the siren in the bedroom will sound too.
Note: You can have up to 5 Birdi devices
in one location that connect through the free app on your phone. If you subscribe to the service plan you can have an unlimited amount.
Can I buy Birdi for my office or my second home? Or to help me watch over my
child, elderly parent or pet?
Of course! And the more you buy, the
cheaper they become. Remember: we’re here to make life better and want to help
you as much as we can. You can access them all from the same free app or even
from a landline, in case grandma doesn’t have an iPhone. Unfortunately, Fido
can’t get alerts on his collar just yet, but that's why we're opening up our API to the community.
Does this replace my existing smoke and/or carbon monoxide alarms?
If your battery-operated smoke alarm is
working, then you’re in the minority. Most disasters happen not because people
don’t have alarms, but because the ones they have don’t have working
batteries. Birdi can add protection if you already have some working ones, or
it can work as a totally stand-alone system.
One of the benefits of replacing the
current system is that all the Birdi’s are wirelessly interconnected together in a flock (multiple station). So if
one goes off, they all do, and you’re alerted about the location of the danger
through the app.
Plus, with Birdi you decide whether it’s
an emergency or false alarm right from your phone so that you don’t have to
deal with confusing security systems or third-party notifiers. It could even
save you money because those false alarms usually come with fines of $100 and
up from the fire department. Each false alarm that we prevent covers the cost
of another Birdi, saving you money!
Please note that this device is not officially a smoke and/or CO alarm until it receives certification from the appropriate body, which will happen before it becomes available.
Can I choose the color that best matches my walls?
You spend a lot of time and money

decorating your house. We want to help you by blending in. Not only is our design simple and clean, we also come in a number of colors so that it can blend even further. It's our stretch goal to have multiple colors. If we reach $100,000, we'll introduce colors. The first batch is meant to be a beautiful addition to a
newborn’s room or to a colorful living room. If you want a certain color, we
may include it in the next batch. Just let us know!
Can anyone setup a Birdi?
Yes. Simplicity is core for us. Birdi was
designed to streamline setup. The app syncs your wifi settings with your
device by singing a custom bird song. It’s our new BirdiSync technology and we
think it’s pretty cool. Just take Birdi out of the box, BirdiSync your settings,
and place it on the wall. Our universal mount makes ceiling installation easy too. It’s that simple.
Can I get my neighbor a Birdi?
Neighborhoods are physically connected
and now they’re digitally connected. If your neighbor has a fire, it’ll alert
you too (if they've opted in). It’s safer than finding
out by hearing the fire trucks roll up. At that point,
it might be too late.
1h: Is it available in
my country and/or language?
Birdi is international. We’re available for worldwide
shipping. This is tricky, so there’s an additional charge for supporters
outside of the USA (sorry!).
We speak a bunch of languages (and growing!). Currently we
communicate in: Arabic (العربية), Chinese (中文简体), English, French
(Français), Russian (Русский), Spanish (Español), Afrikaans‎, Pirate (Yarrrrr). If you want to translate Birdi into another language,
we’ll add it to our app and credit you on our site as an awesome person: https://www.transifex.com/organization/birdi
The certifications we’re obtaining reach far and wide, but
please be aware that if they don’t comply with your local safety regulations,
you should not use this product as a safety device.
Be aware of any additional costs you may be responsible
for, such as import fees or VAT. We’re working on setting this up so that you
don’t have to worry about it, but aren’t there yet.
Up to FAQ
What are the shipping costs?
Free shipping in the USA. While we are committed to being international, global shipping is more difficult for us at his stage and so has an additional cost.
Please be aware that we do not include extra fees from customs or any other
additional costs associated with countries outside the USA. While we're
confident that we will function well around the world, there is no guarantee
that this will work in your country due to climate & connectivity issues.
Of course, if we find out that shipping isn't possible, or if we find out any
other issues regarding your country your perk will be reimbursed.
When is the soonest I can get a Birdi connected in my home?
Incubating a hardware is similar in ways to incubating a child. Working with our manufacturers to take this to full
term, we've collectively planned shipping to start 9 months after our campaign ends and after we

know the scale of our first run. We're doing all that we can to ship the perks that we promised and estimate shipping to begin in October 2014. This is after we've also completed the time-consuming process of receiving the necessary safety certifications to deliver you the safest possible product. We promise that our campaign supporters will be the very first to have them once they ship. If you're planning to
have a child, now is the perfect time to reserve yours!
Up to FAQ
Will Birdi work with Android, Blackberry, Shnosberry, etc?
We are designing Birdi so that it will
work with any web-enabled device, with extra features to enhance the experience
in our native app. Prior to launch, we are developing for iOS and Android.
Can I use multiple phones with my Birdi?
Yes. The app is free and one Birdi device
can connect to several smartphones and landlines. Whether they're family or friends, little Birdi tells everyone.
How is Birdi powered? What happens if the power or WiFi goes out?
The first version of Birdi runs on batteries and
communicates over wifi. If the batteries are running low, we'll send you an
alert way in advance and send you a new battery way before the old one runs
out. We're happy to do anything we can to make you breathe a little easier.
Since we operate over wifi, if it does happen to go out, the device becomes a
regular smoke and carbon monoxide alarm, sounding the siren if it senses
danger. In the worst case scenario, Birdi will still be a smoke and carbon monoxide alarm. We'll also let you know if the wifi has gone down for any significant
amount of time. Down the road, we may even help you send a frustrated letter to
your service provider, because we know that not having wifi is no joke.
What voltage does Birdi Support?
Birdi comes with standard AA batteries.
You can find them just about anywhere in the world. This is part of our plan to always be as accessible as possible.
How long do the batteries last?
Our AA batteries last for about 2 years.
We’ll warn you when they’re getting low and send you a new set if you’re
subscribed to our service.
How long does the carbon monoxide (CO) sensor last?
We can guarantee a 7-year lifespan due to
existing government regulations. But our device learns over time and will

update the settings as it calibrates to your home over the years. Our Carbon Monoxide sensor is pre-certified with UL2034, and we’re doing everything we can to make sure it can keep on protecting you as long as possible beyond those 7 years without needing replacement.
Can Birdi detect other emergencies like tornados, earthquakes or alien
invasions?
Yes. We'll be introducing geo-fenced alerts for emergencies. There was a time when a local
emergency would cause the civil defense siren to sound and we'd turn on our
radios to wait for instructions. This system doesn't work well for a lot of
people anymore. We seek to augment the existing systems by sounding the alarm
in your home too, so that you have added protection when you're home. If
there's a sudden local emergency like a tornado, flood, or otherwise, our
device will sound the alarm. If there's an alien invasion, well, we all have
bigger problems. But we will find a way to let you know, and get to work on creating a new translation set. This feature will be in the experimental phase and only
available in certain areas until we can roll it out fully.
Can I mount Birdi on a wall or ceiling?
Birdi was designed to seamlessly blend in
with the ceiling. It can also work on a wall in certain situations where it can
still detect smoke, as in accordance with fire codes.
Do multiple Birdi devices communicate with each other?
Birdi
devices are wirelessly interconnected and function as a multiple station smoke
alarm. If it goes off in the kid’s room, it also goes off in the kitchen. This
generally works they’re 50ft (15m) apart or closer. Some features may reduce
their range, like the type of building material, ductwork, or other large
metallic objects.
Does Birdi work with my existing smoke and carbon monoxide alarms?
Birdi is a multiple
station smoke alarm so that when it goes off in the kitchen, it also goes off
in the bedroom. However, it only works that way with other Birdi devices. Other
companies have proprietary systems that we can’t communicate with. Similarly,
some devices have a wired interconnect between devices.
Up to FAQ
What are the health impacts of PM 2.5?
The air we’re breathing is causing
cancer. The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), a part of the
World Health Organization (WHO), has now classed air pollution in the same
category as tobacco smoke, UV radiation and plutonium. PM 2.5 relates to fine
particles, which contain large amounts of toxic and hazardous substances that
stick in your lungs. Causes include cooking emissions, oil soot, and industrial
processes, as well as second-hand smoke.
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-24564446
How do you detect smoke?

We use a photoelectric sensor, which uses a beam of light to detect smoke. These alarm types are most effective for typical residential fires, that originate from a smoldering source, which can also fill a home with dangerous gases even before the fire ever erupts.

Older smoke detectors used ionization sensors, which use radioactive material to detect small particles entering the chamber. These ionization sensors were originally designed to detect heat, not smoke, and so do not respond fast or at all to slow smoldering, smoky fires which are the most common types of residential fires. These were typically used due to their significantly lower cost. Common belief is that one of these ionization sensors is necessary for flaming fires, but research done by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has shown that during a flame ignition fire, the photoelectric smoke detector has only a 3.99% probability of a failure to detect the fire whereas the ionization detector probability of failure is as high as 19.8%. Besides that, ionization sensors have been the largest cause of nuisance alarms (in one case, 97% of devices tested for nuisance alarms were ionization-type). This frustration encourages homeowners to remove or disable their smoke alarms. Given the significant amount of research testifying to their poor performance and unreliable nature, we believed that the future of smoke detection should not rely on using cheap sensors that use radioactive material. http://fire.nist.gov
Wait, the smoke alarm on my ceiling has radioactive materials?
About 90% of existing smoke alarms do. They use
ionization to react to fires. These ionization chamber smoke detectors contain
radioactive material. The radiation source is a small disc, about 3 to 5
millimeters in diameter, weighing about 0.5 gram and made of americium-241 in a
gold matrix. Because they are inexpensive, ionization detectors are more
common. We decided
that radiation wasn’t a good idea for our device. You can learn more about the different types of smoke alarms here - http://www.ul.com/global/eng/pages/corporate/newsroom/storyideas/smokealarms
What about cigarette smoke?
You’re covered. If you have a strict no
smoking policy, you can enforce it. We can even track the amount of smoking
that’s happening.
4e: Why should I be more concerned about carbon monoxide (CO)?

Carbon monoxide poisoning is a very serious threat and we strive to do everything we can to prevent this silent killer.It is an extremely deadly, colorless and odorless gas, not to be confused with carbon dioxide (CO2). In small amounts, it replaces the oxygen in your bloodstream, causing suffocation usually without any obviously apparent symptoms. It is released in varying amounts by most combustion sources, such as boilers, stoves, car exhausts, smoking, space heaters and even the pilot flames in your gas stove. Symptoms of poisoning include dull headaches, weakness and dizziness, which are not good enough indicators on their own to let us know that something is dangerously wrong. Other carbon monoxide sensors are only supposed to alert you when threateningly high levels are sustained. These detectors give you no idea of your exposure until it is an emergency and it starts beeping. At that point, carbon monoxide poisoning may have already caused confusion and delirium, leaving you in a state where you can't act on the alarm effectively.These devices are not meant to alarm for at least 30 days at 30ppm, which is enough exposure to cause headaches and dizziness within 6 hours. At 70+ppm, the alarm only has to start in 60-240 minutes.With the Birdi app you will be able to track your CO in your home with about 2ppm accuracy. You'll be able to spot a leak long before it gets to a dangerous level, so that you can act on it and get the help that you need. You'll get a detailed message from Birdi explaining exactly what to do and if it's an emergency, we'll alert the right people as quickly as possible.
What can I do if the air is bad?
We give you tips that you can use. If the
air is bad, we’ll send you warnings. You can set your level of sensitivity to
be less or more informed. If the air is better outside than inside, we may tell
you to open a window. If not, we’ll tell you that’s not a great idea. And we’ll
help direct you to air purifiers, humidifiers, dehumidifiers, and plants that
can help improve the conditions inside your home. Our marketplace will use the
data from our devices to tell you which purifiers are working the best, so that
you can make informed purchases based on real results.
How does air impact my sleep?
Bad air means bad sleep. It can reduce
the quality of sleep but more dangerously, air pollution increases the risk of
sleep-disordered breathing, a group of disorders including sleep apnea, in
which breathing stops briefly during sleep. Up to 17% of U.S. adults have
sleep-disordered breathing, according to Antonella Zanobetti, PhD, a senior
research scientist at the Harvard School of Public Health.
http://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/news/20100617/air-pollution-linked-to-sleep-breathing-problems. If humidity is too
low, skin gets dry and chapped and it can exacerbate psoriasis and quickly
lead to respiratory disease. If humidity is too high mold can proliferate in your home.
How does air impact my child’s sleep?
Air dangers are especially acute with
children and the elderly. Babies have sensitive skin and even more sensitive
respiratory systems. During the winter-time, when central heaters are turned on
and indoor humidity drops to 10 percent or less, the dry air can irritate a
baby’s skin, nose, and lungs. This cold, dry air also helps viruses to grow.
Furthermore, when babies come down with a cold or respiratory infection, they
cannot take the same over-the-counter drugs that an older child or an adult
can
column2: their small bodies are too fragile for strong medicines. For all of these

column1: reasons, pediatricians frequently recommend humidifiers for babies, especially
in dry climates.
4i: How does monitoring for carbon dioxide (CO2) help me?
Carbon dioxide (not to be confused by carbon monoxide, the extremely deadly gas that we also monitor for) is produced by almost all living things, especially us.

Long exposure to small amounts can affect your concentration, energy levels and can cause headaches. But besides that, a buildup of CO2 indoors means that you have not gotten fresh air in your house for a while, which is an indicator of other harmful effects, such as the buildup of fumes slowly given off by your furniture, paint and other household compounds, or just an indicator that it’s time to open some windows. In that case, we will be able to let you know.

Larger levels of carbon dioxide can buildup in areas that store carbonated beverages, or when there is some form of combustion occuring. Levels of around 3% will cause you to start breathing at twice your normal rate, and cause dizziness, increased heart rate and blood pressure, while above 10% can cause suffocation. But Birdi will warn you and the people that need to know long before that happens.
Do you monitor for mold?
By
tracing particulates in the air and following humidity levels, we’re able to
help warn that mold might be growing. Edward Olmsted, an industrial hygienist
in Garrison, N.Y., puts it best: ""Mold is like a factory that produces
billions of spores,"" he said. ""The factory runs only when moisture is
available. Eliminate the moisture, and you shut down the factory."" While
we can’t yet monitor for mold itself, we can warn you about moisture levels.
Do you monitor for radon or gas?
No. Exposure
to radon in the home is responsible for an estimated 20,000 lung cancer deaths
each year in the USA. That’s more than drunk driving. Radon is a radioactive
gas that poses a serious health hazard. We don’t detect for that or gas leaks, but you should.
Learn more about how to do that here - http://www.epa.gov/radon/pubs/citguide.html
Do you help prevent sick building syndrome?
Yes.
The following causes have been cited as contributing factors, according to the
EPA: inadequate ventilation, chemical contaminants such as volatile organic
compounds (VOCs), stale air, biological contaminants and more. We both monitor
and give tips on how to improve air-flow based on the air both indoors and
outside.
Up to FAQ
How secure is it?
Our security is as strong as a bank, if
not stronger. All communication between your Birdi, the cloud and the app is
encrypted over SSL (HTTPS).
5a: How private is my information?

All of your information is private and visible only to you and people in your inner circle who you specifically invite to see it. Any data available through the API is abstracted so that an individual's information is never visible.
5c: Can I turn it off for privacy?

You can, though we don’t recommend it. At any point, your device can become a regular smoke alarm if there's either no internet connection or if you choose the privacy mode where it will stop broadcasting. Birdi keeps your information private and accessible only by those you choose to trust.
Up to FAQ
Can it monitor Carbon Monoxide if its mounted on the ceiling?

Yes. According to the CO guidelines of the National Fire Protection Association, carbon monoxide alarms should “be centrally located outside of each separate sleeping area in the immediate vicinity of the bedrooms,” and each alarm should “be located on the wall, ceiling or other location” according to the manufacturer’s recommendations.
There’s a common myth that carbon
monoxide (CO) sensors are supposed to be placed at “knee height” because CO is
heavier than air. CO is actually slightly lighter than air and diffuses evenly

through rooms. Besides, the source of carbon monoxide is usually warm, like a boiler. In this case the carbon monoxide containing air will be more likely to rise to higher areas of your home. Typical sensors are often plugged into wall outlets as a convenient power
source, placing them close to the floor in rooms.
Besides, we give you pre-warnings that
show you visualizations of carbon monoxide levels, even if they’re not yet an emergency.
Does it work with… (my connected lock, camera, security system, etc.)?
Our OpenAPI will allow certain integrations to work out of the box. As a regulated security
device, there are certain difficulties with opening the platform SDK and ensuring
the required reliability. At the same time, we believe a truly smart home is an
open one.
Will there be an SDK or API?
Birdi would love to have an SDK.
Unfortunately, this is a device to ensure security and because of that have to
limit some functionality. Having an open API is very important to us too and
this we can achieve. We want to give everyone more details about the air we're
all breathing and want data scientists to help develop those insights and
developers to create cool new solutions.
Up to FAQ
What are the challenges?
Smoke alarms tend to be annoying. And air quality devices are confusing and expensive. While the sensors exist and are reliable, combining the functionality
is truly unique and there's nothing else out there which comes even close. We're working with the top manufacturing experts to bring this device into
every home with realistic and achievable deadlines and promise to be open and
transparent about any delays that come up which are beyond our control.
Where are you crafting this product?
Birdi is designed in Brooklyn, developed
in San Francisco, and manufactured in Shenzhen. Deciding where to produce
products is never easy these days. For Birdi, we started at the Cleanweb
Hackathon in NYC and worked on our industrial design and graphic design from
there. Then we joined Highway1 in San Francisco and started building the next
iterations of the technology, beyond our initial prototype. For manufacturing,
we needed to go to China, the sensor capital of the world, since our product is
packed full of them. Throughout, we want to make sure that our production
process is transparent and sustainable. If you’d like, you can even see who
we’re working with and learn about the conditions there. It’s important to us
that everyone who touches Birdi is positively affected and that includes the
workers who build our product to the customers who enjoy it.
How environmentally friendly are you?
It’s important to us that making Birdi
doesn’t have a negative impact on air quality. We’re making Birdi as green as
possible from the packaging to the casing to the factories that they’re built
in. While every other smoke detector and air quality monitor is made from oil,
ours is actually made from pollution. That’s right, we’re removing pollution
from the air to make our case. It’s recaptured CO2, and we hope to set a
precedent for other companies to follow suit. Our production line has a team of
specialists to constantly monitor it to find ways to improve environmental
sustainability. Worker health as social sustainability is important to us too.
So much that Birdi is available in some of the factories so that we can monitor
the air there and work to improve it. And of course, our packaging is 100%
recycled and recyclable. Once the sensors are no longer active, around 7-10
years depending on our testing, we’ll help guide you to local recycling facilities to
reduce the environmental impact at the product’s end of life.
Who made your video?
We were lucky to work with Prashant
Bhargava as the director. You’d be pretty lucky to work with him and his team
too. Check him out: www.prashant.tv
Who made the music for your video?
The guys at WE Sound Labs were incredible
to work with. Quick, responsive and solid. http://wesoundlabs.com
Does it work for the deaf, blind or otherwise handicapped?
We're doing what we can to make sure that our system works for people with all kinds of disabilities, in ways that traditional smoke alarms never have. Curtis from Florida reached out to us
early in our development and mentioned that he lives with two deaf people. He
requested that we build Birdi with accessibility in mind and we responded. In addition to the visual alerts that people receive on their phones in case
they can’t hear the alarm, we also have a color-coded system (green for good,
red for trouble), that flash from the device. Since nearly 10% of the country
is color blind, we also make sure that it flashes in different patterns
depending on the state of the emergency.
Does the device
talk?
Birdi
sends you verbal notifications directly to your phone, otherwise, we sound the
alarm, blasting the siren as loud as we can so that you and your loved ones can
get to safety. Our service also talks directly to 911, letting the right people
know about the emergency as soon as possible.
How loud is the
siren?
LOUD.
Regulations mean that the alarm has to be 85 decibels (dB) at 3 feet, which is critical in an emergency. We’re
louder. How loud is that? Well to give you some idea, a train whistle is 90dB
at 500 feet.
Did you change your name?
We were initially called Canary, as in
the “canary in a coal mine” that would tell you if there’s a gas leak by dying.
That was pretty morbid, besides, there are a lot of products on the market
called Canary from the past few decades. We like the “a little birdy told me”
analogy a lot more.
Design change?
Our designs are explorations around the
core idea of a bird. We’ve looked at elements like flower, nest, egg and more.
The initial design was base",51.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","New York, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/birdi/pica

column7:
>We are jamii fund 

In January of 2013, jamii fund was founded in West Palm Beach, Florida. Our founders are a close-knit group of people with a passion for helping others. We set out on a mission to put an end to one of the biggest problems facing the hardworking citizens of the United States
column8:
medical debt. 
We did this because we believe that enough is enough. No longer should people have to sacrifice a meal to pay their hospital bills. No longer should someone have to refuse the care that could save their life, just because they don't have the money to for pay it. Enough is enough.
We are focused on putting an end to this social injustice that has become commonplace in our society. We are helping real people, with real problems, and we're making a real change for the people that need it most. We are facing a very serious challenge, and we know that it may sound crazy, but medical debt can become a thing of the past in our lifetime. Join us in making that dream a reality. 

What We Need &
column9:
What You Get

We are trying to raise $10,000 to get our feet off of the ground. We will use this money to pay all of our startup fees, build a user-friendly website to host our fundraising efforts, and create marketing opportunities to expand our influence. All of that will not cost $10,000, so what remains will be disbursed among the people that we are already helping.

column1: To sweeten the deal for you, you will receive a lovely t-shirt with a $35 donation. This super stylish shirt will instantly improve your wardrobe, and tell people that you are a smart and caring individual that loves to help others.
Why jamii fund?
We are a very unique platform for a few reasons.
<div><ol>
<li>
We are a nonprofit organization (for real, we have the paperwork and everything). That means that your money is not going into the pockets of some greedy executive, but directly to people in need.
<li>

We do not take a percentage of the contributions made to an individual profile. So when you donate $100 to help Rick from Reno, $100 goes towards supporting Rick from Reno. We are not in the business of taking money away from those that we help. They need it more than we do.
<li>

We are run by volunteers (and I'm not talking about Tennessee athletics). That means that no one is getting paid for the work that is done by jamii fund. Everything that you see is the labor of people working from the goodness of their heart.
<li>

We screen every potential case for fraud. Every individual that receives funding from jamii fund must go through a process to verify a legitimate need. This way you can feel safe in knowing that your contribution is not going towards paying for someone's ticket to a Beyonce concert.

Other Ways To Help

Everything that jamii fund does depends on people knowing that we are an option. If you hear about someone struggling with medical debt, send them our way. If you see a story on our site that moves you to act, act! Share it with your friends on social media, or contact us about holding a fundraiser in your community. The possibilities are endless.

We are also looking for partners on campuses throughout the country. If you are interested in working with us to form a partner organization at your school, please don't hesitate to contact us. We will work with you through the process of establishing an official organization, and with rallying support on your campus. We believe in the power of young people making a difference, and this is a great way to do it.
hello@jamiifund.org

PLEASE HELP OUT OUR FRIEND

This past year our dear friend Christine Glen Coussee, ovarian cancer survivor and warrior woman, was faced with another bout of cancer that set her back. She was pretty well cancer free last year and was about to move on with her life and rejoin us in the production of TWIST and SHOUT at Drayton, when the cancer came sneaking back this summer. We would like to help her with the financial burden of her recent treatments of chemo, the added expenses surrounding that and make sure the cancer is kicked right out of the ring! You can help in a big way.
WHO AM I?...
column2: >I am a good friend of Christine and have been since 2005, performing in
column3: >TWIST AND SHOUT and LEGENDS
column7: > for quite a few years. She has one of the most incredible singing voices I have EVER heard. She is blessed beyond belief. She also is a mother and a loving wife. If we have our way, this woman is not leaving this planet any time soon!

column1: ANYTHING HELPS!...
column2: >Whether it's 5 bucks or 50.....Please help us reach our goal by giving generously or anything you can. Every bit counts. We just want Christine to get this chemo out of the way so she can live her life and continue letting the world enjoy the gift of her voice and so she can continue to be the kick ass mother and wife she is.

column1:
Thanks for your time and contribution. 
These funds will be personally delivered to Christine with a warm smiles and a big hugs.
Love and Healing,
Duff MacDonald
On Behalf of the Cast, Crew, Band and Creative Team of

","PLEASE HELP OUT OUR FRIENDThis past year our dear friend Christine Glen Coussee, ovarian cancer survivor and warrior woman, was faced with another bout of cancer that set her back. She was pretty well cancer free last year and was about to move on with her life and rejoin us in the production of TWIST and SHOUT at Drayton, when the cancer came sneaking back this summer. We would like to help her with the financial burden of her recent treatments of chemo, the added expenses surrounding that and make sure the cancer is kicked right out of the ring! You can help in a big way.

WHO AM I?... I am a good friend of Christine and have been since 2005, performing in TWIST AND SHOUT and LEGENDS at Drayton Entertainment in the Toronto area for quite a few years. She has one of the most incredible singing voices I have EVER heard. She is blessed beyond belief. She also is a mother and a loving wife. If we have our way, this woman is not leaving this planet any time soon!

ANYTHING HELPS!...Whether it's 5 bucks or 50.....Please help us reach our goal by giving generously or anything you can. Every bit counts. We just want Christine to get this chemo out of the way so she can live her life and continue letting the world enjoy the gift of her voice and so she can continue to be the kick ass mother and wife she is.

Thanks for your time and contribution. These funds will be personally delivered to Christine with a warm smiles and a big hugs.Love and Healing,Duff MacDonaldOn Behalf of the Cast, Crew, Band and Creative Team of Twist and Shout: The British Invasion",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns
|","Toronto, Canada",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/christine-s-kick-the-cancer-fund/pica

Help us reach our goal of a Home Birth!

With a View!

Baby number two is a welcome surprise to our family. But funding our
commitment to home birthing has been a small challenge as we
strive to move away from the fast-paced, make-money-to-spend-money

culture we were used to. While we will count on hundreds of volunteer hours for the bulk of the support we need, there are many expenses related to a home birth that are not covered by our health insurance or by volunteers: The Midwife and her assistant = Birth plus prenatal and postnatal mommy and baby care for roughly 9 months total service  = an investment in the magical adventure of delivering a new child to the world. 

As is our family tradition, we are asking for a community gift. We will
not be having a baby shower as we saved most everything we need for
round two. If you were hoping to buy the baby a little something, this

is your chance. This is the support we need.

The land we welcome our new child to is supporting our family in many ways. Ways we can share with you as a thank you for your support of this ""project"". Please peruse our offerings to the right. There is no limit on the number of perks you can sign up for and most can be given as gift to others. If you want a Pint and a Kiss, sign up for both, you get the idea.

You are our tribe and we are deeply grateful for all the ways you support and nourish us. We hope to reciprocate in every way we can.

Love,

Luke, Janet, Terra and new baby :)

P.S. With your help our little homestead is growing and putting down roots
for the long term. BIG THANK YOU to everyone who gifted fruit trees

this winter, little flowers and leaves are starting to bud!

I am Leah Pusateri, and I am a survivor of a traumatic injury. I have spent the last year healing from my injuries, and fighting every day to restore my body to health. Now, I am looking for help to raise $4,000 towards the purchase a Continuous Passive Motion Machine to alleviate the pain I experience in my knee, improve my ability to walk, and continue the process of healing.

As the passenger on a scooter on June 26 of 2012, I was struck by an uninsured motorcyclist and sustained severe injuries. My right femur broke out through my skin and a piece of it snapped off, my knee was damaged, my right and left arms were fractured, my clavicle fractured, a few ribs were fractured and my skull was fractured. So much blood was lost at the site of the accident, that I had no detectable pulse upon the arrival of EMS.

I have had 3 surgeries in the year since the accident. The immediate trauma surgery, a bone graft from pelvic bone to my injured femur, and the last surgery was March 5 of 2013- to clean up scar tissue behind my right knee (which was preventing my knee from bending) and to replace hardware in my leg. The healing from this last surgery called for the use of a Continuous Passive Motion Machine (or CPM) to try to increase the mere 58 degrees my injured knee was able to bend.

The CPM is only financially covered by health insurance for a short period of time, though the benefits of the machine are great and the machine improves my daily functioning. I have lost the ability to do many things I once enjoyed such as hiking, rock climbing, river walking, and jogging with my dog, to name a few- my use of the machine alleviates the nearly constant pain I have in my leg, and improves the bend in my knee and my ability to walk.

I want to make a full recovery, not just for myself, but for those I can inspire. I have recently become affiliated with the Trauma Survivor Network and am in training to be a Peer Counselor at Metro Health Medical Center, for recent survivors of traumatic injury.

I couldn't have made it through this experience without the support of my family, friends, and community. I have been supported in so many ways physically and emotionally, and now I am asking for financial help. I will continue to strive for a life of recovery and health and with your help I will purchase the Continuous Passive Motion machine that will facilitate that.

*Many thanks to my friend, Madeline Hoyle for their assitance with this project! Video produced by Madeline Hoyle, a freelance designer in Cleveland, Ohio. http://www.mhoyledesign.com

My name is Renee, I am writing asking for help for my dear friend Robin Griffin and her family. Robin and her three sons have been struggling for over 3 years with several rare medical diagnoses. Her oldest son Daniel is 17.  He has Chiari Malformation, Ehlers Danlos Syndrome (EDS), Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome, Tethered Cord Syndrome, Cranio-cervical Instability, True Right Single Coronary Artery, VSD and Basilar Invagination.  In three short years he has endured 2 brain surgeries, tethered spinal cord surgery, rib graft surgery, heart catherization for 2 congenital heart defects and occipital cervical fusion, (fusion of skull down to c3).  His cranio-cervical instability and Chiari was life threatening and serious because it was causing both anterior and posterior compression of the brainstem.  These surgeries were necessary for his safety and quality of life. He still struggles with oxygen levels dropping to low 80's in certain positions.

Her middle son Stephen is 13 and also has EDS, Post Concussive Syndrome, Cranio-vertebral Instability, Basilar Invagination, Short term memory loss and CAPD. His instability and Basilar invagination also life threatening requiring occipital cervical fusion (fusion skull to c2) with rib graft. He too is suspected of having Tethered Cord Syndrome.

Her youngest son Hunter is 5. Although he has not been confirmed due to his age as formally having EDS it is strongly suspected. He has Autism and Oral Dyspraxia and has been receiving intervention services since he was 8 months old. His MRI has also revealed the same cervical instability issues as his brothers and one day may also require surgical intervention.
Robin is 46 years old, she too has EDS. She has had cervical fusion of c1 &
column2: c2, hip graft surgery and Tethered Spinal Cord release surgery with symptomatic Tarlov Cysts removed.  She also has preglaucoma and an enlarged optic nerve and Intercranial Hypertension.  He instability was compressing her vertebral artery on rotation.

column1: Chiari (kee-ar-ee) Malformation - is a hind brain herniation of the cerebellar tonsils/lower brain down and out of the skull and into the neck. It is caused by a malformation of bones within or near the skull and/or the pulling from below by Tethered Cord Syndrome. Daniel's Chiari herniated 12mm where it lead to compression of his brainstem and obstruction of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is a connective tissue disorder. Connective tissue acts like ""glue"" in the human body, holding everything together. Collagen, a protein that adds strength to the connective tissues, is not produced correctly in an individual with EDS. The resulting weak connective tissues are too weak to hold the organs, ligaments, joints, etc. of the body in place. It is currently separated into 6 major types.
Robin's family has Hypermobility EDS with vascular components.

Individuals with EDS are at risk for cranio-spinal instability (CSI), which often results in cranial settling. In cranial settling the tissues in the neck are so weak (due to EDS) that the cervical bones are not held in place. Slumping or collapsing onto itself occurs. This usually leads to abnormal angles/malformations of various bones and this can lead to both anterior and posterior brainstem compression. These malformations force the cerebellar tonsils out of the skull into the spinal column through the small hole at the base of the skull called the foramen magnum, a phenomena called cerebellar herniation, AKA Chiari. When the cerebellar tonsils are out of place, they take up space normally allotted for the cerebral spinal fluid (CSF), the brainstem, and all the arteries and veins leading through this area to the brain. Blockage can be both posterior and anterior. The cerebellar tonsils are the lowest part of the cerebellum, which controls the sensory perception and motor control systems of the body. The brainstem controls the autonomic nervous system, or everything your body does without you having to think about it, heart rate, respiration, blood pressure control, etc. Damage to these systems is very serious. CSI may also allow the Odontoid bone at the front of the neck to angle into the brainstem (Retroflexed Odontoid), causing even more concerns, such as Basilar Invagination or Basilar Impression. (Brainstem Compression). Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS) is a type of dysautonomia. It is also commonly seen with individuals who have EDS and EDS with Chiari as a result of brainstem concerns. In addition to this, an individual with EDS and instability is at risk of subluxation (partial dislocation of bones) of the neck or abnormal sliding of the skull in flex/extension, further compromising the brainstem, tonsils and vertebral arteries. Making this life threatening for some.

Tethered Cord Syndrome (TCS) -  In this condition, a band of connective tissue called the filum is wrapped around the base of the spinal cord and exerting pressure on the nerves that go to the legs, pelvis, bladder and bowel. This leads to leg pain, weakness, numbness, scoliosis and many more issues.

Robin and her sons struggle daily with various significant neurological symptoms involving the brainstem and EDS (and for Daniel also the cerebellar functions).  Some of the symptoms they struggle with are severe headaches, neck pain from subluxations, tinnitus, swallowing difficulties, visual disturbances or vision loss, a sensation of pressure behind the eyes, autonomic nervous system dysfunction (POTS, neurally mediated hypotension), sleep disturbances, brain fog, (seizure for Daniel), memory issues and over all full body joint instability causing painful dislocations and subluxations.

There is no cure for these conditions, only stablization for better quality of life.  Although the surgeries have been successful in treating their major concerns and easing some of their pain there are still issues that will be life long. They continue to go to physical therapy to which they have been in for 3 years.

Because their combined conditions are very complex few doctors are able to help them.  They are fortunate to have an expert pain management doctor locally however their neurosurgeon and geneticist are located in Maryland, Cardiology in Boston and NY.  Robin, her husband and sons live in New York State.  The combined total of 8 surgeries and constant traveling 6.5 hours out of state one way for surgery, tests, and follow-up appointments has taken a great toll on them both emotionally and financially. They have insurance but it's limited for out of network benefits.   After processing they still owe several thousand dollars and have more upcoming appointments to attend to out of state. Estimated bills owed currently are around $10,000.  More expenses will be coming up and more bills owed as more tests are need and possible surgeries too.  They struggle daily in trying to make ends meet, living pay check to pay check.

They recently learned their secondary insurance which should have covered the out of state co-pay expenses for surgery will not be.  This was devastating news. The bills owed will increase more as a result.

Robin is the rock of the family and an inspiration to many who share these diagnoses. She has worked hard in getting her sons and herself to the doctors they need, sacrificing what she can to do it.  She is unable to work due to the pain associated with EDS, her older son is also part-time home bound from school because pain and endurance limit his ability to atttend school. In addition to devoting her time to helping her sons she also spreads awareness of these rare complex conditions by successfully managing a support group of nearly 900 members online.   I’d like to help her through this difficult journey like she has helped so many others.

Please help the Griffin family any you can, any donation big or small can make a huge difference! You can also help by saying a prayer for them, sharing this page with all of your contacts, whether through email, facebook or twitter.
Thank you SO very much!

My mom was in a car accident and is suffering from many injuries. She is not able to do much and she lost her job as a result of this. While she was in the hospital, they found some health concerns. My mom needs to have an MRI, a Catscan, and a Biopsy done ASAP. Her insurance only covers a portion and she has to pay the rest. Please help my mom raise the money she needs to get her necessary tests done. So she can get the treatment she needs to get better. I only have one mom and I don't want to lose her. Please, please help her!

Hello,
We are La Fuente Prosthetics and our Foundation is called Hope For Healing.
Twice a year we visit Honduras to provide for those in need of maxillofacial and ocular prosthetics as well as assist with surgeries that the people of Honduras are not able to afford.
Types of services we provide:
Maxillofacial and Ocular prosthetics:
Nose
Ear(s)
Eye(s)
Orbital with Eye.
These types of prosthetics cost between $1850-$4850.00
Surgical procedures we provide:
Henry La Fuente has developed a Bone Replacement to aid with those that have minor to major bone deformities.
This procedure is specifically designed for those who have sustained injuries and never healed properly.

Many of these people with deformities are either born with them,  caused by the civil war or work related injuries.

These procedures are very expensive and we provide services to those who are unable to afford it.

How you can help:

Traveling to Honduras can get expensive.
Although we supply everything necessary, we still need your help to continue our work.

The cost of flights for our team:
$800 per person round trip x6 = $4800
Hotel accommodations for the week:
 $108 a night and 3 rooms = $2268
The Cost of shipping for our equipment:
$2000 round trip
The Cost of Food:
$100 per person per day =$4200
Transportation Cost:
$50 per person per day =$2100
Miscellaneous Cost for surgical rental supplies:
$4632
Total Cost= $20,000.00
This cost is a fraction of what we spend on the procedures and the use of the materials required to create the prosthetics.
All funds raised will go to this budget regardless if the full amount is reached.


The Impact

Ranging from the young age of 7 to age 60. Our patients are discouraged about the way they look or how they are unable to preform their daily routines with their deformities.
These people need your help to get us there.
Risks
Honduras is the murder capital of the world. It is very dangerous in the part of Honduras where we travel. We risk our lives to help these people.
In The Media
We have been featured in several times in The Oklahoman
Other Ways You Can Help
We know everyone is not able to contribute, but if you can share this campaign with your friends and family, that would be greatly appreciated.

<div style=""text-align: center

A smart yet simple device that will notify when you or your loved ones took their last dose of pills - and will remind you when to take the next one.
Notifications can be provided directly to cap or to your mobile device.
<h3 style=""text-align: center
column2: >The perfect solution for the entire family

column1: <div>

We currently have a working prototype and app and we're now focused on:
<ul>
• Package Designing

<div>
<h3 style=""text-align: center
<div>

We have been working on iRemember for the past year and we've come a long way. But now we need your help. Your support will allow us to initiate tooling and manufacturing so we can make iRemember available to you and the millions of people around the world. Let's create better medicine management which will improve our life quality.
So why should you support us?
<ul>
• Be the first to get one.
• You want to have no worries about your dear ones taking their medicines on time.
<li>You believe in our product and the benefits it can deliver to the healthcare system.<span style=""background-color: initial
<h3 style=""text-align: center
<div>
<strong>
<b>1a: How many iRemember devices do I need in my home?

Depends on the level of medicine usage of your family. Each iRemember fits one box of pills. We recommend to have iRemember device for you and each one of your family members who use medicines on a regular basis.
1b: Can I use iRemember to monitor the doses taken by my child or elderly parent?
Sure! You can let them use iRemember and monitor their medication usage from the same app. Moreover, multiple people can access the same iRemember device from their apps, if you grant them access.
1c: Can anyone set up iRemember?

Absolutely! iRemember was designed for the purpose of making installation a thing of the past. iRemember is one single device, designed for everyone to be able to use. Simply, take it out of the box, set time interval and you're done. It’s that easy.
2a: What are the shipping costs?

All shipping in the US is free of charge. There is additional cost for international shipping. Shipment does not include extra fees from customs, or additional costs associated with your country. If it turns out that shipment to your country proves impossible, we will reimburse your order.
2b: When is the soonest I can get iRemember?

Estimated shipping dates for the device begin in June 2015. Our goal is to have the shipment out to you earlier but we wanted to make sure not to overpromise. we are working around the clock to bring this to market, and as soon as it’s ready, it will be sent out to you!
3a: Can I connect multiple iRemember devices with my mobile device?

Yes. You can simultaneously connect to many iRemember devices, using the free app.  For instance, if there are two elderly users in home, you can monitor both of their iRemember devices 24/7, from the same app.
3b: Can I use multiple phones with my iRemember?
Yes. The app is free and a single iRemember can be connected to multiple phones. For instance, if there is a child in home, both of his parents can monitor his iRemember device.
3c: How often do I need to charge iRemember?

We worked hard to develop a device with low electricity consumption. If connected to mobile device, iRemember needs to be charged only once a month. If not connected to mobile device, iRemember needs to be charged once in few months.
3d: How do I charge iRemember?
You can easily charge iRemember with any USB cable.
<div style=""text-align: center
<div style=""text-align: left
3e: How do I connect iRemember to my mobile device?
You can connect iRemember to your mobile device using bluetooth. We are currently working on developing Wifi connection as well.
4a: What are the challenges?

We are doing something that has never been done before: a completely revolutionary device like nothing else in the market. While there may be manufacturing and production delays outside of our control, we promise timely and transparent communication throughout the process. Soon, iRemember devices will be managing the medications intake of many families.
4b: How can I contact someone from the iRemember team?
Please visit our contact page in our website or directly contact our CEO at: moore@wealthtaxi.com
Any more questions? Ask away!
We hope you join us.
","Meet iRemember.

A smart yet simple device that will notify when you or your loved ones took their last dose of pills - and will remind you when to take the next one.Notifications can be provided directly to cap or to your mobile device.
The perfect solution for the entire family

iRemember is easy to setup on different sizes of pill bottles or organizers.It monitors the times of doses taken so it can alert you if your family forgot to take their pills on time.Moreover, iRemember can tell when was the last time a dose was taken by simply pressing the top button of the device or using the mobile app.
Simple to understand and intuitive to use
iRemember setup takes less than 1 minute. All is needed is to choose the way and how often you would like the notifications.

In order to activate the mobile option - simply download the app and connect it to your iRemember device. Integrating iRemember with your mobile device enables great features such as notifications to family members/professionals and a battery level indicator. iRemember can even sync to your calander and setup your medication schedule.
Receive notifications from anywhere

With iRemember, the app and primary service are free and can be integrated with as many iRemember devices as you'd like. That means you can download the free app and receive notifications from all family members.

Moreover, future development will enable more data options such as heads up before you run out of pills, sending vocal massages to your family caps and FDA updates. iRemember can also be used without any phone integration.
Anyone will use it
iRemember can be used for vitamins, suppliments and medications such as birth control pills.  It is beneficial to many people in different age groups.
Cheaper and better than all other solutions
We set out to disrupt the medication management market by designing a solution that addresses the major consumer pain points of existing products.
Smart solution for saving life
Some important facts to know about medication mismanagement:
Its the 4th leading cause of death in the U.S with an annual death toll of 125,000 in the U.S only.
Its the cause of 700,000 annual hospital visits in the U.S only.
Its the cause of 25% of nursing home addmissions.
$177-$300 Billion estimated annual cost to U.S healthcare system.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Compatibility
iRemember is designed to fit different bottle sizes, including bottles from the 5 major U.S pharmacies, as well as pill orginazers.
Perks for our Indiegogo contributers
Here's a breakdown of the perks you can choose from when you support this campaign (select your perk from the sidebar at the top of this page).
The iRemember team
Where are we in development
We currently have a working prototype and app and we're now focused on:
Package Designing
Getting product certifications
Designing the supply chain process
Tooling
Materials procurement
Production
Why we need your support

We have been working on iRemember for the past year and we've come a long way. But now we need your help. Your support will allow us to initiate tooling and manufacturing so we can make iRemember available to you and the millions of people around the world. Let's create better medicine management which will improve our life quality.
So why should you support us?
Be the first to get one.
You want to have no worries about your dear ones taking their medicines on time.
You believe in our product and the benefits it can deliver to the healthcare system.
Questions & Answers

3c: How often do I need to charge iRemember?

4a: What are the challenges?

While there may be manufacturing and production delays outside of our control, we promise timely and transparent communication throughout the process. Soon, iRemember devices will be managing the medications intake of many families.

Cortlin Jackson, also known as Cort, is on his way to Cooperstown, New York, home of the Baseball Hall of Fame.
For one week in June of 2013 Cortlin (along with his 11 teammates on the North Gwinnett Bulldogs Travel Team), will embark on the journey of a lifetime- Well in the lifetime of 12-12 year olds.
He will play baseball in the Dreams Park Tournament. Over 1,350 Teams per Season visit the park to learn &
column2: compete and just have genuine fun!!!!

column1: As part of his experience, Cortlin will be immortalized by being inducted into the prestigious American Youth Baseball Hall of Fame where he will be enshrined. As a part of the Cooperstown Dreams Park experience, he and his teammates will also be awarded the coveted American Youth Baseball Hall of Fame ring - like the champions before them - and granted membership into this distinguished baseball club.
Cortlin is currently North Gwinnett’s center and right fielder.
Favorite Athlete- Cam Newton
Favorite Baseball Player- Andrew Jones
Favorite Movie- Spiderman
Favorite Food- hamburgers
Hobbies- building leggos....hard ones
Please help him realize his goal to play @ Dreams Park in the 12U tournament of a lifetime.

About us:
My name is Sandra Taylor. I live in Lake Worth, Florida. I have a beautiful family, and a goofy Great-Dane dog named Jake. In my hometown, Costa Rica, I have the rest of my large family.
But, our family is incomplete, and we want to adopt our beloved Samantha and bring her to the USA to live with us.
What are we doing:

We’ve been trying to adopt Samantha for five years now, since she was two days old! She is a Costa Rican child, and her legal guardians are my sister and her husband. The international adoption process was moving along just fine for the first year, and all the adoption papers were submitted. But, suddenly Costa Rica froze all international adoptions for three years, due to a moratorium—a law process that interfered with adoptions.

Well, during these three years Samantha grew happy and beautiful, sweet and easy going. Unfortunately, she also got sick! She got ""nephrotic syndrome,""a condition where the filters in the kidneys become leaky, releasing large amounts of proteins into the bloodstream, causing ""oedema"" or fluid retention that causes swelling.

Samantha’s face, legs, and stomach swelled up, and she started to complain about being tired and that she had stomach aches. One morning her eyes were swelled shut, and we rushed her to the hospital, where they admitted her for fifteen days. It was a horrible experience for all of us, and she learned to be terrified of needles and nurses in general. She has been sick three times, same problem, and the doctor in Costa Rica gives her heavy doses of steroid medication that last up to 6 months to reduce the swelling, and help alleviate other issues. The problem is that this recurrence of the disease/medication weakens her kidneys, and there is the probability that she may come down with kidney failure...

Our family is stressed out of our minds! We pray constantly and cry a lot. We need help adopting Samantha, so we can place her under the care of a renal specialist that may cure her, before she needs kidney replacement.
What we need:

The international process of adoption is open again, but our original papers are outdated, and Costa Rica requires a new set of them. It happens that our funds are exhausted, and we are in a difficult financial situation. We need to put together $20,000 to cover:
<ul>
• Home study
• Dossier
• Lawyer in C.R.
• Deposit for half of the money toward her adoption
• Fingerprinting
• Child passport
• Child airfare
• Child review of referrals
• Paperwork in C.R.
• Medical exam
<li>
Child immigration documents
• Translations
• Visa
The impact:
For Samantha, your support means the difference between a healthy life, or one of dealing with the horrors of kidney dialysis or transplants. Your help will bring her beauty and personality forward
column2: she will be a happy baby, not one that suffers on a daily basis.

column1: What you’ll get:

Our family offers our most sincere gratitude for your support. We promise to keep an updated profile of Sam's progress under the specialist care, and many pictures of Samantha in the Facebook page we are putting together. Your support will make an enormous difference in her life!
I also offer to send each one of you that gives us a helping hand some of my paper cut-outs. Those I cut one by one and are made on sturdy bond paper. They’re very beautiful.

Thank you for taking the time to lend us your valuable moments of the day! Even if you’re not able to help us monetarily, we would appreciate you sharing this with all your friends and family so the word gets out to the right people. Thank you so much!! We really appreciate you and hope to have our little girl in our arms soon!

Christine's Story
Hello! My name is Christine and I have been an aerialist for five years and have been dancing since I was three years old. After graduating from college with a double major of dance &
column2: biology, I decided to put my pre-physical therapy degree aside (temporarily) and pursue my performance dreams. Since then, I have been living a simple life dedicated to training, performing, and teaching both aerials and dance. I am very lucky and very grateful to be able to support myself entirely on performing &amp

column1: I perform for many different kinds of events from festivals &
column2: churches to clubs and conferences. Most of my performance work was with a small juggling company that did a lot of shows for school aged children. Kids' faces light up when they see someone flying and defying gravity. It's amazing. Teaching was my other income. Giving people the strength and courage to do the impossible is a very satisfying thing. When you work hard to defy odds and succeed, you want to show others that it is entirely possible! When your students make progress, you succeed. I don't own a fancy car or live in a swanky house, but I sure am happy doing what I love.

column1: On October 14, 2012, I had an accident which shattered my wrists and dislocated my elbow. I was hospitalized for seven days, in casts on both arms for over two weeks, and then I was in a hinged elbow brace for over a month. The surgeon is happy with my progress and has told me that if I work hard every day, that I will be back in the air and back to my life! It has been a long couple of months, and I am still not quite there. I have a lot more healing to do, followed by a lot of strengthening, conditioning and stretching. Needless to say, I will be out of work for at least a couple more months...
Where Exactly Is Your Generous Contribution Going?

I did not have health insurance when I got hurt. Since my accident, I have been getting by solely because of the generous help and love of my friends and family. Medical bills keep rolling in and are now over $55,000. We are making every attempt we can to get discounted rates and charity care, but we are unsure of how much that will cover. So here I am, asking for your help to pay these bills so that I can get back to inspiring and spreading smiles, strength &
column2: courage to as many people as I can.

column1: * * * IF YOU MAKE A DONATION, PLEASE E-MAIL ME YOUR CONTACT INFO! That way I can get your perk to you! Thank you so much!! (Name, e-mail, mailing address) contact@christinemorano.com
<div>
What Do You Get In Return?

The benefit show in Philadelphia on Saturday January 12, 2013 was amazing and wownderful. I am so grateful and blessed and lucky to have such magnificent, talented, generous people in my life. The performances of dance, circus, physical theater, and jazz trio performances were perfect and more than i could have ever asked for. We had two packed shows thanks to each of you! I hope you all enjoyed it.
TO SEE PHOTOS OF THE SHOW GO TO THE LINKS BELOW:

Some of the art donated by local artists still has yet to completely sell. If you are interested in SevenPly skateboard jewelery, ceramics by Miss Millie, or private canoe lessons on the Schukyll River, please contact me at contact@christinemorano.com
You can still donate! All other perks still apply!
A Kind Donation of $15 will get your name on our Sponsor Board which will be up at the show. I will also send you photos of the Board in case you can't make the show!

A Very Kind Donation of $50 will get you a hand written Thank You card from yours truly. I will probably add some doodles and excitement to said card. You will also get a silly photo of the show's cast of performers. (Maybe they will write you notes, too!)
A Super Generous Donation of $500 will get you 4 private lessons from me as soon as I'm back &
column2: flying! (Which will be no later than this summer!)

column1: An Amazingly Generous Donation of $1500 will get you a video of a complete aerial act made just for you to the song of your choice.

If my goal is not reached, whatever money that is collected will still go towards my medical bills. As I said before, they are well over $55,000. The goal on this site is set low... feel free to go above and beyond!
<div>
The Impact
Your contributions will help me get back into the air to start work on new pieces and shows, and to start teaching again!
The mother of two students who I have been teaching private aerial lessons to over the past year wrote:
<div><span style=""font-family: Arial
column3: >""I know they both feel that they would not have been able to do aerial acts at camp without your teaching and Jeremy is a better dancer because of it.  That was a little boy who couldn't climb a rope and now he can climb it and hang upside down from it while doing acrobatic moves!!!!  It not only helped him physically but also helped to boost his self-esteem.  You helped to change his life.

column1: <div><span style=""font-family: Arial
column3: >I hope everything works out for you and we are anxious to get back as soon as you are ready.""

column1: <div>
Other Ways You Can Help

Want to help but are unable to financially? Trust me, I understand! How about just spreading the word? If you use the Indiegogo share tools enough, my campaign could be featured on their site. Make some noise! =)

TO SEE PHOTOS OF THE SHOW GO TO THE LINKS BELOW:

Some of the art donated by local artists still has yet to completely sell. If you are interested in SevenPly skateboard jewelery, ceramics by Miss Millie, or private canoe lessons on the Schukyll River, please contact me at contact@christinemorano.com
You can still donate! All other perks still apply!
A Kind Donation of $15 will get your name on our Sponsor Board which will be up at the show. I will also send you photos of the Board in case you can't make the show!

A Very Kind Donation of $50 will get you a hand written Thank You card from yours truly. I will probably add some doodles and excitement to said card. You will also get a silly photo of the show's cast of performers. (Maybe they will write you notes, too!)
A Super Generous Donation of $500 will get you 4 private lessons from me as soon as I'm back & flying! (Which will be no later than this summer!)
An Amazingly Generous Donation of $1500 will get you a video of a complete aerial act made just for you to the song of your choice.

If my goal is not reached, whatever money that is collected will still go towards my medical bills. As I said before, they are well over $55,000. The goal on this site is set low... feel free to go above and beyond!
The Impact
Your contributions will help me get back into the air to start work on new pieces and shows, and to start teaching again!
The mother of two students who I have been teaching private aerial lessons to over the past year wrote:

I know they both feel that they would not have been able to do aerial acts at camp without your teaching and Jeremy is a better dancer because of it.  That was a little boy who couldn't climb a rope and now he can climb it and hang upside down from it while doing acrobatic moves!!!!  It not only helped him physically but also helped to boost his self-esteem.  You helped to change his life.
I hope everything works out for you and we are anxious to get back as soon as you are ready.""
Other Ways You Can Help

Want to help but are unable to financially? Trust me, I understand! How about just spreading the word? If you use the Indiegogo share tools enough, my campaign could be featured on their site. Make some noise! =)",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

Meet StarVox, the world's first smartwatch with a built-in walkie-talkie. Its innovative design ushers in a new era of unconstrained outdoor communication by allowing you to contact friends and family without the need for cellular reception or bulky handheld radio equipment.

No matter if you are hiking through the forest, climbing the highest peak, or escaping for a weekend of camping, there is no need for bulky radios or endlessly searching for a mobile phone signal. StarVox not only eliminates these problems with its walkie-talkie feature, but also functions as a superior smartwatch that frees you from additional items to keep track of and carry.
<div data-id=""14139619""><figure style=""margin: 0px
Big ideas often come from small packages, and StarVox is no exception. The on-board antenna facilitates easy communication with others within a 2 KM radius.

","Meet StarVox, the world's first smartwatch with a built-in walkie-talkie. Its innovative design ushers in a new era of unconstrained outdoor communication by allowing you to contact friends and family without the need for cellular reception or bulky handheld radio equipment.

No matter if you are hiking through the forest, climbing the highest peak, or escaping for a weekend of camping, there is no need for bulky radios or endlessly searching for a mobile phone signal. StarVox not only eliminates these problems with its walkie-talkie feature, but also functions as a superior smartwatch that frees you from additional items to keep track of and carry.
Big ideas often come from small packages, and StarVox is no exception. The on-board antenna facilitates easy communication with others within a 2 KM radius.
Talk freely where there`s no cell network
Frequencies will be adjustable according to different countries/regions
StarVox doesn’t simply allow for communication with another person, but in fact opens up the conversation to a whole group. StarVox supports unlimited member in the group chat.

StarVox is a smartwatch at its core and does not miss a beat with its included features and functions. StarVox is engineered to perfection with all expected functions of a modern smartwatch plus a few extra such as: on-board compass, a hygrometer, and a barometer.
