My name is John Harper. I am the Founder and CEO of Rize.

Two and a half years ago I found myself feeling incredibly low, lost and unable to do much of anything. I was unable to focus, I found it difficult to stay out of bed for more that a few hours at a time, interact with anyone without feeling anxious, and worst of all I had no idea what was wrong with me.

After visiting my GP a few months later I found out I was suffering from moderate depression. I couldn't believe it. I couldn't have depression. I felt weak somehow..but at the same time I realised that something tangible and real was happening to me...I wasn't just crazy, or lazy or being moody.

From there I decided to work on myself first - I was a young man not ready to share his feelings with other people. So I did my research - I started going on website's that provided a lot of information on depression and how I can face my negative thought patterns to help myself. I looked at apps, videos, documentaries, journals, books, and even went to a few conferences. The content of all of these were admittedly dry and quite boring, but I forced myself to get through this, as I understood the importance of what this information could do for people.

Eventually I started feeling better and able to get out into the full world again. I started talking to a counsellor, I got a job as a Research Assistant and I started playing music again. I still had some horrible lows, but from all that I had learnt I was able to develop an understanding that there was actually a light at the end of the tunnel. I kept having nagging thoughts in the back of my head though - 'How many other people have gone through the same thing as me? How many of them didn't find the right support to help them? How many people desperately need support right now?'

I started doing research in my spare time. I researched for myself all of the best, scientifically-proven methods to help people  --  not only those with depression, but everyone -- to improve their mental well-being. At the same time I researched the prevalence of depression, anxiety and stress. The results were shocking:
1/4 of the UK population will experience a mental illness in the course of a year, with depression and anxiety as the most common problems.
The World Health Organisation describes depression as the leading cause of disability in the world.

I began talking to a lot of people - psychiatrists, people with depression, other people with no previous history of mental illness. Wherever I went I found there was a huge demand for an engaging and simple way for people to access, understand, and practise the best ways to improve our mental well-being: our focus, ability to manage stress levels, our mental health, our confidence, and cognitive abilities. People are now beginning to grasp the importance of understanding our thoughts, emotions, and mental health in all areas of our life. Football players have training to improve their focus and mindset, celebrities and politicians integrate mindfulness into their daily lives to manage their stress, and the demand on the NHS to support the public's mental well-being is growing.
Introducing Rize:

We are creating a multi-platform app that integrates therapeutic concepts into simple information and interactive exercises to help those who need it to understand, track, and improve their mental well-being.

By providing only the best, proven methods to support mental well-being we know this can help a lot of people. We are not providing a platform to treat people suffering from depression, but an environment in which anyone can enter and learn the basic concepts of improving their mindset, well-being, and performance.

Rize has already made a big impact, and before we've even finished the full Rize app we've received overwhelming response and support from the Accelerate Cambridge Program, the London Institute of Psychiatry, MindTech, and a large group of counsellors in the Cambridgeshire area.
I've put the last 15 months of my life into this project, my savings, and my heart. I truly believe in what my team is creating here to make a powerful impact in the world, to help a lot of people.

We're at the final sprint now. The full version of Rize will be available on iOS in a week's time, with just a few additions in functionality to be made. Our business timeline had relied on receiving a grant that we had high hopes for that would allow us to develop Rize for Android, iPad and Tablet. Unfortunately we were successful in getting just under half of what we needed.

We're looking to raise £5k. This will go directly into product development: I can pay my Developer and Designer to complete the final changes and create the app for Android, Ipad and Tablet, so that we can truly reach the wider global population.

Once Rize is available in the app stores it will be available for £2 per week. We've especially designed the app so that people who contribute to this crowdfunding project will be given a code that they can use to access Rize for free. The more you contribute now, the longer you can have full access to all of our content and exercises.

Our biggest risk right now is running out of money. Don't worry, one way or another Rize will be complete and ready. But the sad truth is that in one month we won't have enough money to continue development. I will raise the funds one way or another in the end - getting a job, busking with my guitar, selling my desk for firewood - there's no way that I won't be getting Rize out there and helping people. With your help we can get it out there a lot faster, I can keep my desk, and together we can help a lot of people.

So go ahead, fund this project now! Every minute you wait is another minute you could have been using Rize to supercharge your mental well-being! Don't forget to share this project with your friends, co-workers and family - as many people as possible.
","My name is John Harper. I am the Founder and CEO of Rize.

Two and a half years ago I found myself feeling incredibly low, lost and unable to do much of anything. I was unable to focus, I found it difficult to stay out of bed for more that a few hours at a time, interact with anyone without feeling anxious, and worst of all I had no idea what was wrong with me.

After visiting my GP a few months later I found out I was suffering from moderate depression. I couldn't believe it. I couldn't have depression. I felt weak somehow..but at the same time I realised that something tangible and real was happening to me...I wasn't just crazy, or lazy or being moody.

From there I decided to work on myself first - I was a young man not ready to share his feelings with other people. So I did my research - I started going on website's that provided a lot of information on depression and how I can face my negative thought patterns to help myself. I looked at apps, videos, documentaries, journals, books, and even went to a few conferences. The content of all of these were admittedly dry and quite boring, but I forced myself to get through this, as I understood the importance of what this information could do for people.

Eventually I started feeling better and able to get out into the full world again. I started talking to a counsellor, I got a job as a Research Assistant and I started playing music again. I still had some horrible lows, but from all that I had learnt I was able to develop an understanding that there was actually a light at the end of the tunnel. I kept having nagging thoughts in the back of my head though - 'How many other people have gone through the same thing as me? How many of them didn't find the right support to help them? How many people desperately need support right now?'

I started doing research in my spare time. I researched for myself all of the best, scientifically-proven methods to help people  --  not only those with depression, but everyone -- to improve their mental well-being. We're looking to raise £5k. This will go directly into product development: I can pay my Developer and Designer to complete the final changes and create the app for Android, Ipad and Tablet, so that we can truly reach the wider global population.

0,"

Cancer is a killer

I'm sure most of us have been touched by cancer in someway or another, whether it's a colleague a friend, family member or even yourself. It's probably one of the most grueling treatments any one person has to go through. It's months of radiation and chemo treatments the leave you ill and unable to live a regular life, the strength required to continue living a day is something cancer patients have to struggle with each day.

Liesl has been through a lot of it and has shown incredible determination to beat it no matter the odds, she blogged about her journey through her ordeal and has been on various radio shows to invite people to learn more about the disease and how to react and cope with the news. 

I implore you to read her story here - http://liesldb.co.za/ 

Not all have been as fortunate as Liesl and some friends have already been lost to this dreadful disease. An amazing re-awaking happens when you experience something of this magnitude of how life is so precious and forever fleeting. We need to sieze the moments we're given and live them in as much joy as we can.

We only want to help Liesl get back up on her feet and recover from her financial loss which exceed R80,000 in medical bills not covered by her medical aid.

Cists on lower spinal cord has left him paralyzed from the waste down.  This situation revealed itself with no warning.  Vet is on a VA program.  Two options:  1). Open back surgery [requires two surgeons plus entire ER team
column2: 1 week to 10 days in the hospital
column4: three to six months recovery plus an additional six months rehab].  2). Laser surgery [requires two to four hours outpatient procedure
column6: possibly three to six days bed rest

column1: This man was in the process of packing go and tend to ailing parents who are themselves in dire straights.  This sudden event has turned many lives up-side down!  The laser clinic is in the same city as his parents.  He really needs to get over this injury as soon as possible to BE ABLE to tend to his parents.
Vet can probably get partial to full reimbursement from the VA but that could take months.  ALL MONIES RECEIVED AS REIMBURSEMENT FROM THE VA WILL BE PROPORTIONTELY RETURNED TO ALL DONORS!
Open back surgery is scheduled for November 1st by the VA and it is his final option, AND HE IS VERY THANKFUL TO THE TAXPAYERS FOR EVEN DOING THIS MUCH!!!
Vet served seven years in the U.S. Navy, completing three tours in the Persian Gulf.

If the amount needed for the laser procedure is not raised in time, the Vet will still be out of work and unable to support himself for about six months following the open back procedure and he has no one that he can turn to for assistance to get through this period.
He currently lives frugally in a studio apartment.  He has already sold his 2004 Jeep for $4,500.00, (couldn't drive anyway), and is currently living off those funds but they are quickly running out.

As stated, he would have left for his parent's city almost a month ago now had it not been for this situation.  He's half packed and was suppose to be out of his apartment by September 1st.  But the landlord has said he is good through the end of December if he needs it, (which he will), and if he can pay the rent.

Vet spearheads the local annual ""Tools-4-Tots"", (school supply drive), and the ""Toys-4-Tots"" toy drive each year in his community.  ""Toys"" is coming up real soon and he needs to be able to function so that he can pull it off.  So many things to juggle!
Any donation amount would be greatly appreciated!
Lord Bless you!!!

Charisse Tyson, Jake's sister

column2: >Our dear friend, Charlie Cordova, is in need!

column1: My Name is Alina .  My Father, Charlie Cordova is in need of a life saving liver transplant. He was recently diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma cancer which has currently declined the health of his liver dramatically. He is currently on the liver transplant list in Arizona and is awaiting that important call we all  hope for very soon. My mission for this fundraiser is to help ease his financial burden of medical expenses that have arised from recent and future hospitalizations in link with his liver transplant surgery that we hope he gets very soon, daily perscriptions before and after transplant, doctor visits, current and furture home nursing care, etc..  The total cost of a liver transplant these days is $500,000 thats including his out of pocket costs as well with insurance. Hes been a 2 to 3 job hard working man and dedicated father and recently had to retire due to health reasons from the DJ/Broadcasting  business and a COT and CWA member  at Qwest Communications Telephone company of over 30 years strong.

For over 25 years, Charlies been knows as  Goodtime Charlie ""The Outlaw DJ,"" who  provided countless Missions From God Fundraisers  for those in-need. From funeral costs, to medical expenses needed for families with hardships of all kinds, Charlie was there to help. Hes always been  a man to be  the first to put out his hand to help someone in need. Now , Charlie is in need of a life saving liver transplant. We need to raise money to help him and his family! His medical bills alone are going to be extremely large, not including the regular bills of life.
Please help us by passing this along and spreading the word about
a great man in need.  YOU can help make a difference in the life of a man who's done so much for so many!!
Thank you all and God Bless.
Charlies daughter
Alina McCaslin

Ever forget to change your ac/furnace air filter or take your medications including birth control?  You aren’t the only one.  We forget many things?
Clean Air and Asthma
<ul>
• More than 24 million Americans – including 7 million children – suffer from asthma (EHS Today)
• Reducing indoor air pollution can have a dramatic impact on the effects of asthma. (Clean Air Plus)
• Changing the air filter is probably the most missed item of maintenance that homeowners fail to do.  (Anderson/Schoech, Attorneys at Law, Real Estate)
• A dirty air filter is the #1 reason for HVAC system failure.
• 90-95% of AC service calls to rental units are the result of not properly changing air filters.
• A dirty AC filter is hazardous to your health. The Trane website explains, ""The air inside your home is usually more polluted than the air outside.”
<li>

Air pollution may double the risk that an elderly person will be hospitalized for pneumonia, according to a study.  (News Max Health - Dirty Air Doubles Elderly Pneumonia Risk Thursday, December 24, 2009 8:13 AM)
Medication Noncompliance (I forgot my mediation/birth control)
<ul>
• The American Heart Association calls the #1 problem in treating illness today is failure to take prescription medications correctly.
• 1 million unintended pregnancies occur every year from pill user failure.
<li>
55% of the elderly don't take medication according to the doctor's orders (Agingcare.com)
<li>
62% of participants in a study conducted by US National Library of Medicine National Institutes of Health forgot to take medication.
• In 2006, Align Map cited a survey that 49% said they had forgotten to take prescribed medications.
Pet Medication
<ul>
<li>Heartworm disease occurs in 66-100% of dogs exposed to mosquitoes and who live in endemic regions.
<ul>
<li>
Dogs should be given heartworm medication on the same day each month YEAR-ROUND.
• 50% of pet owners fail to administer pet medications as directed
• 30% of pet medication doses are not given in the prescribed time
Other forgotten tasks
Mustang Express (4-2-12) listed some of the top 10 things people forget include:
<ul>
<li style="""">
<ul>
• Taking medication
• Feeding the pets/fish
• Taking out the trash.
• Watering the plants
• Changing water filters
• Children’s chores
Who We Are

Jim Novak is the founder of the Daily Timer.  His son has severe asthma and doctors said it was very important to change the AC filters on a regular basis for cleaner air.  Jim looked for a user-friendly reminding device for regular filter changes.  After researching online, two things were discovered
column2: there wasn’t a timer that counted down in days and there were many forgotten tasks that could be eliminated by this simple device.  Thus, the Daily Timer was born.

column1: ASI (Advertising Specialty Institute) -  the largest media and marketing organization serving the advertising specialty industry with over 50 years of experience and 27,000 distributors/suppliers as members.  ASI will be the initial ""mass marketing"" source.
DA International:  a global manufacturer, which has over 22 years of experience in custom manufacturing and product development.
Our Goal

The requested funds of $30,000 will bring the Daily Timer to life.  The funds will be used for the first run of 10,000 units including a minimum order of 100,000 computer chips.  These prices include everything from production, printing and delivery to the end user.

90 days is the expected manufacturing time for the first round of units.  Time will be significantly reduced for orders thereafter.   We have teamed with a proven manufacturing and distribution company.
The Impact

The Daily Timer is a simple device to help its users to remember important tasks such as taking medication as prescripbed or changing air filters for cleaner air.  These are two of the most forgotten tasks for all of us.  Ask any doctor if they have clients that forget to take their medications – I can tell you what you’ll hear.   Ask any parent with an asthmatic child if having a simple device to remind them to change their air filters regularly is useful.
Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the word out.   Send our campaign link to anyone you know that could benefit from the Daily Timer.  Think of doctors, nurses, home healthcare providers, HVAC companies, or anyone with asthma. We look forward to updating everyone on the Daily Timer’s success.  Thank you for your support.

Hello, my name is Marandah Field-Elliot, and I'm a seventeen year old student at Santa Barbara High School. Two summers ago, I had the opportunity to travel alongside Educational Safaris to the Amazon Basin of Bolivia for a three week volunteering, language, and cultural immersion adventure. On June 29th, 2013, I have the honor of returning to Bolivia for my second El Puente Trip along with a wonderful team of Middle and High School students.

The goal of El Puente 2013 is simple: to aid the the Rio Beni Health Foundation in any way that we can. Our trip will be split between time in the Rurrenabaque medical clinic and journeys to surrounding rural villages to install and check on Bio-Sand Water Filters.  These filters are easy to construct, made with inexpensive materials, are self-sustaining, rarely require upkeep, and are incredibly effective. Since the number-one cause of death in Bolivia is waterborne illness, the filters are vital.
However, this fundraising campaign isn't about us
column2: it's about the foundation. It only costs $3.50 per person per year for Bolivian healthcare. Our 2013 fundraising goal is $6,000, which would provide preventative healthcare and treatment for 1,714 people! Your donation will help the Rio Beni Foundation work with communities and health workers to immunize children, treat illnesses and injuries, and work to help provide the entire Upper Amazon Basin with clean, potable water. Our fiscal sponsor, Direct Relief, insures that 100% of your donation goes directly to our cause.

column1: There are many ways in which you can become involved with the Rio Beni Health Foundation, including:
<div class=""p1"">
<ul>
<li>

Becoming a corporate sponsor. If you work with a business who wishes to make a tax-deductable donation of $250, $500, or $1000, you have the opportunity to be featured on the El Puente 2013 T-Shirt, as well as to be thanked in our Santa Barbara Independent article that will be published in the late summer. This is an excellent opportunity to not only financially support the Rio Beni Health Foundation, but also gain positive publicity. Contact elpuenteteam2013@gmail.com for more information.
<li>Make a private donation right on this site
column2: any amount will help. Once again, the cost of health care per person annually in Bolivia is only $3.50, so even a donation of $5 will honestly change a life!

column1: <ul>
• Share this page! Even if it isn't financially possible for you to contribute, a shoutout on Facebook, Twitter, or an email to your friends will help raise recognition for the cause.
For more information, see www.netzerbrady.org or for information in Spanish http://fusribeln.wix.com/bolivia
Thank you so much for reading, and feel free to contact us at elpuenteteam2013@gmail.com with any questions you may have!
Sincerley,
The 2013 El Puente Team

Two summers ago, I had the opportunity to travel alongside Educational Safaris to the Amazon Basin of Bolivia for a three week volunteering, language, and cultural immersion adventure. On June 29th, 2013, I have the honor of returning to Bolivia for my second El Puente Trip along with a wonderful team of Middle and High School students.

The goal of El Puente 2013 is simple: to aid the the Rio Beni Health Foundation in any way that we can. Our trip will be split between time in the Rurrenabaque medical clinic and journeys to surrounding rural villages to install and check on Bio-Sand Water Filters.  These filters are easy to construct, made with inexpensive materials, are self-sustaining, rarely require upkeep, and are incredibly effective. Since the number-one cause of death in Bolivia is waterborne illness, the filters are vital.
However, this fundraising campaign isn't about us
column2: it's about the foundation. It only costs $3.50 per person per year for Bolivian healthcare. Our 2013 fundraising goal is $6,000, which would provide preventative healthcare and treatment for 1,714 people! Your donation will help the Rio Beni Foundation work with communities and health workers to immunize children, treat illnesses and injuries, and work to help provide the entire Upper Amazon Basin with clean, potable water. Our fiscal sponsor, Direct Relief, insures that 100% of your donation goes directly to our cause.

column1: How to Help
There are many ways in which you can become involved with the Rio Beni Health Foundation, including:

Becoming a corporate sponsor. If you work with a business who wishes to make a tax-deductable donation of $250, $500, or $1000, you have the opportunity to be featured on the El Puente 2013 T-Shirt, as well as to be thanked in our Santa Barbara Independent article that will be published in the late summer. This is an excellent opportunity to not only financially support the Rio Beni Health Foundation, but also gain positive publicity. Contact elpuenteteam2013@gmail.com for more information.
Make a private donation right on this site
column2: any amount will help. Once again, the cost of health care per person annually in Bolivia is only $3.50, so even a donation of $5 will honestly change a life!

column1: Share this page! Even if it isn't financially possible for you to contribute, a shoutout on Facebook, Twitter, or an email to your friends will help raise recognition for the cause.
For more information, see www.netzerbrady.org or for information in Spanish http://fusribeln.wix.com/bolivia
Thank you so much for reading, and feel free to contact us at elpuenteteam2013@gmail.com with any questions you may have!
Sincerley,
The 2013 El Puente Team",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Santa Barbara, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/el-puente-2013/pica

Help me reach my goal for surgery!

* THANK YOU to EVERYONE who helped reach our goal to Save Tom's Hand, in barely 15 hours! This outpouring of support is AMAZING! The best part is, this goal was set as a realistically achievable marker for 42 days, and the fact that we crossed this threshold almost immediately means we can continue to reach for the sky and really put a dent in Tom's medical bills! Let's keep spreading the word, because every bit of this goes to Tom and every dollar counts!! Once again, THANK YOU!!! *
Short Summary

Hey folks, how’s it going? My name is Brandon Baumann. I sing for the band Diamond Lane, and that is how I met Tom Chandler many moons ago. Since 2009 we have worked together closely on many projects and have developed a great friendship therein. Tom is a beloved friend to many, an excellent producer, guitar wizard, writing partner, guidance counselor, co-collaborator and all around go-to-guy. He lives for music and the ability to help create something meaningful that will stand the test of time. He prides himself in making sure those things “don’t suck”, for the betterment of us all really. Needless to say, he has selflessly given so much to so many in our music community without ever really asking for anything in return but thanks. The time has come for all of us to step up and help someone who truly needs a hand.

The point of this campaign is to help fundraise contributions to offset Tom’s currently-sky-high-piling medical bills. He has no health insurance and is facing years of debt, sitting in the hospital as I currently type this.

On February 11th Tom’s dog Sheila bit his left hand, and it has been a subsequent fast track down hill since. His initial Urgent Care diagnosis revealed that Tom received a staph infection in the bite wounds and that antibiotics should wipe him clean in a few days. When his condition only worsened over the next two weeks, Tom went back to the doctor and they ordered him to immediately see a Disease Specialist. It turns out that Tom developed a gnarly anti-biotic resistant form of staph infection that eventually spread into the bone in his middle knuckle on his left hand. To get fancy, Tom has ostiomylitis in his 3rd metacarpal and was immediately rushed into surgery on February 28th.

So now we’re coming up on a full week stay in the hospital, and when he finally gets discharged (hopefully) on Thursday, that will be an expensive, unpleasant week vacation. Thinking about the cost of surgery, antibiotics, anesthetics and delicious hospital food, MRI’s, blood tests, tissue samples, and all the like makes my head spin. To make matters worse, Tom is going to be on IV antibiotics all day, everyday for the next 6 weeks. Once his hand heals, they may have to reopen it to perform a bone graph to replace the bone that they removed from his knuckle. Physical therapy starts immediately.
We’re talking a long, and very expensive road to recovery here. Let’s keep in mind, Tom does NOT have health insurance. Yikes. I can’t even imagine what’s going through his head right now.
Adding insult to injury, Sheila died less than a week after this incident (RIP Sheila Bean). Maybe this was her way of saying “you’ll never forget me”, but whatever it was, is terrible all the same.
<div>
<h3>What We Need &amp

My goal here is to try and raise $3,000. Obviously this will barely put a dent in the debt but at least it’s SOMETHING. I mean, the IV antibiotics are $300 per bag, at 3 bags a day, for 6 weeks….woah. The point here is to show Tom that we CARE. He has selflessly labored through our rehearsals, writing sessions, recordings and temper-tantrums to better the music world. Have you ever heard of or enjoyed

Diamond Lane, Cast of Kings, The Shrill, Bolt Action Thrill, Gun Metal Groove, The Marquee, Fire the Animal, Seventh Day, Raven Parade, Jonah Nimoy, Hollowshell, Brock Bentley??? (I’m certain I’m missing some here)
Well the common denominator here is Tom Chandler.

Beyond that, Tom is a FANTASTIC guitar player and a computer whiz -- Cubase, not ProTools....yet :) -- and to think that he may never function in the same capacity is terrifying. I can’t even imagine what he’s going through emotionally, let alone physically.
<div>
The Impact

In exchange for your patronage, there are a multitude of fun incentives that go beyond the satisfaction of helping out a friend in need. Everything from a simple high-five, a personal phone call and a pitcher of beer to a homemade breakfast or recording of your own song in a high-end recording studio. These are meant to be fun and light hearted as a sincere “thank you”! You gotta know that Tom will be gracious and happy that people actually care.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help

If we don’t reach the goal, that’s fine, every cent (after IndieGoGo takes their small percentage for facilitating the process), of the money will still go to Tom. If we can exceed the goal, then even better. I believe we can. I just didn’t want to throw up a huge number and have people feel intimidated. Every dollar counts. No joke.

Infections, surgeries, hospital stays and lots of post-surgery rehab on the horizon, I want to do my duty as a friend to help any way I can. I encourage you to do the same. If you can’t contribute anything monetarily, that’s totally fine. We’re all broke. I get that. Just pass this page along and spread the word, if you’d be so kind. I know Tom would appreciate that. The fact of the matter is, his influence has impacted and shaped many of the bands you enjoy and see in Los Angeles and beyond, so let’s give a hand to the guy who’s given more than a few. If we all link up and do our part, we can alleviate some of the weight on his shoulders. Thanks for reading.

column2: >1. Hi my name is Roberto Barbero, I´m 26 years old, I finished my degree on culinary arts, so I’m a cook. My dream is to own a business that combines cooking and baking my two big passions, but for a while  I’ve been having troubles to get it done , I have two herniated discs (L4-L5 and L5-S1) which does not allow me to fulfill myself properly within a kitchen, as I have to work more than eight hours standing, I have to carry and lift objects and do physical efforts, which some days I am able to perform with some limitations, but there are others that I can not because the pain and discomfort don’t allow me. I have tried with several treatments to avoid surgery (medication, physiotherapy, swimming, massage, etc.) but none of them has been really helpful to me and I could be that my profession requires a more extreme measure.

>For this reason I ask for your support in order to afford an operation, which has an approximate price of 200 thousand pesos in Mexico (which means the hospitalization, purchase of intervertebral spacers, anesthesiologist, physician surgeon and a part of the after surgery therapy) because at this moment i don't have the money to afford it, I do not have health insurance and as I’m not currently working for any company I have no social security support in my country, which makes it a vicious circle that I love break, to keep developing in the field of gastronomy and in the future to open a source of jobs for people who need it or have special abilities.
>Thank you very much for the support you can provide.

>2. Salut mon nom est Roberto Barbero, j'ai 26 ans, j'ai obtenu mon diplôme en arts culinaires, donc je suis un cuisinier. Mon rêve est de posséder une entreprise qui combine la cuisine et la boulangerie  mes deux grandes passions, mais pendant un moment J'ai eu du mal à faire, j'ai deux hernies discales (L4-L5 et L5-S1) qui ne me laissez pas peux faire face au travaille à l'intérieur d'une cuisine,  parce que je dois travailler plus de huit heures debout, je dois porter et soulever des objets et faire des efforts physiques, que certains jours, je peux avec certaines limitations, mais il ya d'autres jours où je ne peux pas parce que la douleur et l'inconfort ne me laisse pas.  J'ai essayé avec plusieurs traitements pour éviter la chirurgie (médicaments, la physiothérapie, la natation, massage, etc), mais aucun d'eux n'a été vraiment utile pour moi et aussi je pense à cause de ma métier j'ai besoin de mesure plus extreme.

>Pour cette raison, je vous demande votre appui afin de permettre une opération qui a un prix approximatif de 200 mille pesos au Mexique (ce qui signifie l'hospitalisation, l'achat d'écarteurs intervertébraux, anesthésiste, chirurgien de médecin et d'une partie de la thérapie après la chirurgie) car en ce moment je n'ai pas l'argent pour se le permettre, je n'ai pas d'assurance et que je ne suis pas en train de travailler pour n'importe quelle entreprise je n'ai pas de soutien de la sécurité sociale dans mon pays, ce qui en fait un cercle vicieux que je aimer pause, pour continuer à développer dans le domaine de la gastronomie et à l'avenir d'ouvrir une source d'emplois pour les personnes qui en ont besoin ou qui ont des capacités spéciales.
>Merci beaucoup pour le soutien que vous pouvez fournir.

>Hola mi nombre es Roberto Barbero, tengo 26 años y soy cocinero. Mi sueños es poner un negocio propio que combine cocina y panadería, pero desde hace tiempo tengo un problema que me impide conseguir esto, tengo 2 hernias de disco ( en L4-L5 y L5-S1) lo cual no me permite desempeñarme adecuadamente dentro de una cocina, pues son jornadas de más de 8 horas parado, tengo que estar moviendo objetos y realizando esfuerzos físicos, los cuales algunos días soy capaz de realizar con algunas limitaciones, pero hay otros en los que no soy capaz porque el dolor y las molestias no me lo permiten. He intentado con varios tratamientos para evitar la cirugía (medicamentos, fisioterapia, natación, masoterapia, etc) pero ninguna de ellas ha sido de verdad de gran ayuda para mí y en gran medida puede ser que mi profesión requiere una medida más extrema.

>Por esta razón les pido su apoyo para poder costear una operación, (que tiene un precio aproximado de 200 mil pesos en México (es decir, la hospitalización, la compra de los espaciadores intervertebrales, anestesiólogo, cirujano médico y una parte de la terapia después de la cirugía)pues por el momento no tengo los recursos para pagarla yo, no cuento con seguro de gastos médicos y como por el momento no trabajo para ninguna empresa tampoco tengo apoyo del seguro social en mi país, lo cual lo convierte en un círculo vicioso que me encantaría romper, para poder seguir desarrollándome en el ámbito gastronómico y en un futuro abrir una fuente de empleos para personas que lo necesiten o que tengan capacidades especiales.

>Muchas gracias por el apoyo que puedan aportar.

","1. English

column1: 2. Français
3. Español

1. Hi my name is Roberto Barbero, I´m 26 years old, I finished my degree on culinary arts, so I’m a cook. My dream is to own a business that combines cooking and baking my two big passions, but for a while  I’ve been having troubles to get it done , I have two herniated discs (L4-L5 and L5-S1) which does not allow me to fulfill myself properly within a kitchen, as I have to work more than eight hours standing, I have to carry and lift objects and do physical efforts, which some days I am able to perform with some limitations, but there are others that I can not because the pain and discomfort don’t allow me. I have tried with several treatments to avoid surgery (medication, physiotherapy, swimming, massage, etc.) but none of them has been really helpful to me and I could be that my profession requires a more extreme measure.

For this reason I ask for your support in order to afford an operation, which has an approximate price of 200 thousand pesos in Mexico (which means the hospitalization, purchase of intervertebral spacers, anesthesiologist, physician surgeon and a part of the after surgery therapy) because at this moment i don't have the money to afford it, I do not have health insurance and as I’m not currently working for any company I have no social security support in my country, which makes it a vicious circle that I love break, to keep developing in the field of gastronomy and in the future to open a source of jobs for people who need it or have special abilities.
Thank you very much for the support you can provide.

2. Salut mon nom est Roberto Barbero, j'ai 26 ans, j'ai obtenu mon diplôme en arts culinaires, donc je suis un cuisinier. Mon rêve est de posséder une entreprise qui combine la cuisine et la boulangerie  mes deux grandes passions, mais pendant un moment J'ai eu du mal à faire, j'ai deux hernies discales (L4-L5 et L5-S1) qui ne me laissez pas peux faire face au travaille à l'intérieur d'une cuisine,  parce que je dois travailler plus de huit heures debout, je dois porter et soulever des objets et faire des efforts physiques, que certains jours, je peux avec certaines limitations, mais il ya d'autres jours où je ne peux pas parce que la douleur et l'inconfort ne me laisse pas.  J'ai essayé avec plusieurs traitements pour éviter la chirurgie (médicaments, la physiothérapie, la natation, massage, etc), mais aucun d'eux n'a été vraiment utile pour moi et aussi je pense à cause de ma métier j'ai besoin de mesure plus extreme.

Pour cette raison, je vous demande votre appui afin de permettre une opération qui a un prix approximatif de 200 mille pesos au Mexique (ce qui signifie l'hospitalisation, l'achat d'écarteurs intervertébraux, anesthésiste, chirurgien de médecin et d'une partie de la thérapie après la chirurgie) car en ce moment je n'ai pas l'argent pour se le permettre, je n'ai pas d'assurance et que je ne suis pas en train de travailler pour n'importe quelle entreprise je n'ai pas de soutien de la sécurité sociale dans mon pays, ce qui en fait un cercle vicieux que je aimer pause, pour continuer à développer dans le domaine de la gastronomie et à l'avenir d'ouvrir une source d'emplois pour les personnes qui en ont besoin ou qui ont des capacités spéciales.
Merci beaucoup pour le soutien que vous pouvez fournir.

Hola mi nombre es Roberto Barbero, tengo 26 años y soy cocinero. Mi sueños es poner un negocio propio que combine cocina y panadería, pero desde hace tiempo tengo un problema que me impide conseguir esto, tengo 2 hernias de disco ( en L4-L5 y L5-S1) lo cual no me permite desempeñarme adecuadamente dentro de una cocina, pues son jornadas de más de 8 horas parado, tengo que estar moviendo objetos y realizando esfuerzos físicos, los cuales algunos días soy capaz de realizar con algunas limitaciones, pero hay otros en los que no soy capaz porque el dolor y las molestias no me lo permiten. He intentado con varios tratamientos para evitar la cirugía (medicamentos, fisioterapia, natación, masoterapia, etc) pero ninguna de ellas ha sido de verdad de gran ayuda para mí y en gran medida puede ser que mi profesión requiere una medida más extrema.

Por esta razón les pido su apoyo para poder costear una operación, (que tiene un precio aproximado de 200 mil pesos en México (es decir, la hospitalización, la compra de los espaciadores intervertebrales, anestesiólogo, cirujano médico y una parte de la terapia después de la cirugía)pues por el momento no tengo los recursos para pagarla yo, no cuento con seguro de gastos médicos y como por el momento no trabajo para ninguna empresa tampoco tengo apoyo del seguro social en mi país, lo cual lo convierte en un círculo vicioso que me encantaría romper, para poder seguir desarrollándome en el ámbito gastronómico y en un futuro abrir una fuente de empleos para personas que lo necesiten o que tengan capacidades especiales.
Muchas gracias por el apoyo que puedan aportar.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

column2: >Thank you from Marc and The Doty Family","Marcus Robert Doty

column1: Marc Doty was born in Missoula, MT, where he still resides.  Until recently, he worked as a forest fire fighter, which has taken him all over the western United States to help put out large fires from Arizona to Oregon.  After developing a back injury while fighting the West Riverside Wild Fire of 2011, Marc discovered that his injury was more serious than he had hoped it would be.  His sore back was actually a cancerous tumor that had developed over a year and had grown into his spinal cord.
He has been diagnosed with stage 3 Hodgkin's Lymphoma cancer that started near his stomach, moved into his
spinal cord, and has now spread into his lungs and his lymphnode glands in his neck.  He has started treatment by chemotherapy, and will continue to do so for the next year or longer.
Marc Doty's friends and family are reaching out to the public to ask for assistance in raising money to help pay

for the numerous medical expenses that come along with this disease.  A donation account has been set up in his name at Sterling Savings Bank, and we will be holding numerous fund raising events to continue to raise money.
Find us on facebook, at: www.facebook.com/themarcdotyfundraiser
Thank you from Marc and The Doty Family",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns
|","Missoula, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-marc-doty-fund-raiser/pica

As you all know David and I have had a rough few years since his illness started.  Today we learned that he was denied once again for SSD.  We are appealing the decision.  It will take another 9-18 months before we get a hearing date.

I have been taking care of David and also going to work and going to school full time.  With all of David’s appointments for his past and new issues that are going on medically I am most often in the car and at these appointments as he can’t remember things the doctors say or he gets overly anxious and has an anxiety induced seizure.

My work is currently going through a change and I do not have as many hours.  I can’t work full-time or David will lose his medical as I will make too much and I also would have to change hours and not be able to go to his appointments or take him to them.  Current hours are worked around his appointments and school.  I applied for 5 jobs and didn’t get any call backs.  I am still looking for something that will work around his appointments.  I also applied for Work-Study.

I was making payments on a medical bill for me (prior to me having medical coverage) I did not miss any payments and they still decided to garnish my wages and also our checking account.  I had just deposited my financial aid and paid July bills.  The balance was for August and September bills until I receive fall term financial aid.
If I don’t get some help we will be losing our car…the only vehicle I have to get to and from David’s appointments, work and school.

I hate to ask.  But we need help.  I need to raise enough money to pay the next two months bills until I get my fall term aid and work study.  Any amount will help….$10 $20 $5…..Please help me to take care of this so it will be one less stress on David.

I have been taking care of David and also going to work and going to school full time.  With all of David’s appointments for his past and new issues that are going on medically I am most often in the car and at these appointments as he can’t remember things the doctors say or he gets overly anxious and has an anxiety induced seizure.

My work is currently going through a change and I do not have as many hours.  I can’t work full-time or David will lose his medical as I will make too much and I also would have to change hours and not be able to go to his appointments or take him to them.  Current hours are worked around his appointments and school.  I applied for 5 jobs and didn’t get any call backs.  I am still looking for something that will work around his appointments.  I also applied for Work-Study.

I was making payments on a medical bill for me (prior to me having medical coverage) I did not miss any payments and they still decided to garnish my wages and also our checking account.  I had just deposited my financial aid and paid July bills.  The balance was for August and September bills until I receive fall term financial aid.
If I don’t get some help we will be losing our car…the only vehicle I have to get to and from David’s appointments, work and school.

I hate to ask.  But we need help.  I need to raise enough money to pay the next two months bills until I get my fall term aid and work study.  Any amount will help….$10 $20 $5…..Please help me to take care of this so it will be one less stress on David.",0.0,0,"4 Campaigns
|","Dayton, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/please-help-finish/pica

For those of you who don't know me already, my name is J.P.
Baker. I will be attending medical school next year, but I am already looking
to make an impact in health care across the globe. I will be traveling to
Nicaragua this spring to participate in a VIDA volunteer medical program, working
in remote clinics around the country. During this time, I will help provide
primary medical care to impoverished communities, curtailing the spread of
infectious diseases and improving the quality of life for all!
Right now in Nicaragua there are only 0.37 physicians per
1,000 persons (CIA World Fact Book). Moreover, the government can only
afford to spend $335 per person on health care (World Health Organization),
with little of this money going to remote communities. Countless people suffer
from terrible yet treatable diseases such as bacterial diarrhea, hepatitis A,
and typhoid fever.
Your generous donation will go toward funding my trip and providing medical
supplies to the people of rural Nicaragua. As the direct recipient of your
support, I will ensure that your money is used in the most efficient and
beneficial manner. Your donation, large or small, will be greatly appreciated
by me and the people of Nicaragua.
Last year, I participated in a VIDA volunteer medical program in Guatemala.
During this trip I was able to interact directly with individuals afflicted by
intestinal parasites, malnutrition, bacterial infections, and other easily
treatable conditions. As part of a team of 15 volunteers, we provided medical
care to over 300 people over the course of a week. I hope to surpass that
number this year in Nicaragua!

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a="""">Zaira was diagnosed with liver cancer and did 6 months of chemo before she decided to stop the treatments and live her life the way she wanted - she wanted a family with her man Alfonzo.

Not long after that, Rosie was born - a healthy and happy little girl. Rosie was delivered cesarian. While the doctors were in there for the cesarian, they removed a mass of cancerous tumor the size of a softball and handed it to us in an old rusty mason jar - the healthcare system in Guatemala is very poor.

Zaira was happy, healthy and strong all during her pregancy and for the first year after Rosie was born. But, now the cancer is taking hold again. Alfonzo could not cope and left. Zaira is weak, has a hard time walking and passes-out frequently. Zaira's abdomen is distended from the cancer that is growing inside her. Zaira will not be with us much longer. But Rosie will be with us for a very long time and for that we are very grateful :)
Help us set some funds aside for Rosie and Zaira - hospice care, funeral and something to take care of Rosie, after Zaira is gone.

Zaira is a wonderful woman. Zaira has helped us here at Buenas Cosas for years. Zaira even took on the responsibility as coordinator of our Community Center in San Pedro for a year - our volunteers loved her - we love Zaira too :)
Zaira has given much during her 24 years on this planet. Now it's time for us to help her, and Rosie too.
Zaira will be 25 on September 6th. Please help us give Zaira a wonderful birthday present, security for the most important thing in her life... her only daughter, Rosie.
Please make a donation now - anything you can afford is greatly appreciated.

Peace, Love and Buenas Cosas, 


Buenas Cosas
Serving Community &amp
Language Study &amp
Registered Guatemalan Non-Profit

501(c)3 Non-Profit in-process

The Need

The Augsburg Men’s Soccer team uses data to make informed decisions. Our players also use their hearts. Through the VX Sports Monitoring System and Video Analysis System, we monitor both - player data and heart rate - to ensure we create the safest, most developmentally challenging environment in the Minnesota Intercollegiate Athletic Conference (MIAC).
The two systems allow players, to use our already purchased vests:
<ul>
• To track their every movement: distance, speed, # of accelerations, heart rate, etc.
• Use the platforms to reflect and receive feedback to increase their performance goals and growth
• To conveniently access information on their phone on and off campus to prepare for training

Due to COVID, we don't have the funds to renew the software needed for our players to use the systems. Any funds raised over the $5,500 needed will go directly to the Men's Soccer Endowment to support the long term health and stability of the program.
About Augsburg Men's Soccer

For more than 50 years, Augsburg Men’s Soccer has provided a unique experience both on-and-off the field (NCAA Tournaments, International Travel, Canoe Trips, Community Service, Father-Son Mentorship, Take it to the Next Level with Volleyball Rick). We’ve accomplished all of this with talented, driven, and dedicated players, a humble budget, and generous support from students, alumni, parents, and friends.

Due to the impact of COVID, Augsburg’s men’s soccer team faces a budget hurdle. Specifically, we currently don’t have the funds to purchase the annual software renewal of our VX Sports GPS Monitoring System and Video Analysis System, both of which are incredibly helpful to our players. To address this shortage, our coach Greg Holker has assembled a group of former players to help with outreach: Daniel Hedstrom ’19, Blake McReavy ’18, Grant Griffin ’15, Tyler Heaps ’13, Van Hong ’11, James See ’09, Vinnie Brooks ’07, Aaron Riedel ’06, Carlos Martinez ’01, Rob Reimann ’98, Chris Ascher ’81, Mark Anderson ’81, Darcy Debing ’77, and Jim Agre ’72.
Together, Greg, these alumni, and you can help provide the Augsburg Men’s Soccer team bridge the budget gap.
The Numbers
With your contribution, we will be able to purchase the annual software renewals:
<ul>
• VX Sport GPS Monitoring software and support: $3,200
• Video Analysis system: $2,300
Your support will greatly impact our student-athletes by:
<ul>
• Providing stability an continuity in player experiences during COVID19
• Providing the most professional environment possible, including player safety
• Providing opportunity for self-reflection as a soccer player and human being
The Risk

Uncertainty during the COVID19 pandemic may prevent some of you from being able to support this campaign. However, for those of you who can invest, know that your gift to Augsburg Men’s Soccer will bring real, positive impact to our student athletes when they return to campus in a few weeks. If you can't contribute at this time, but still wish to help, please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign by sharing it widely through email, social media, etc.

column3: >  At Saint Francis Organics, we know Mother Nature always has natural ingredients that can take the place of synthetic chemicals. The cleaning and healing power of Saponin makes our hair, body, baby and cleaning household products unique. It does away with the harsh and toxic sulfate chemicals found in almost all household products today. Saponin soothes and nourishes irritated and sensitive skin and has been used by the Nepalese people to treat skin conditions like eczema, psoriasis and acne. You can trust Saint Francis Organics in all your household products to clean, soothe and heal your body.
column10: >Why Reduce Chemical Interference in Our Body?

column1: • The U.S. has the highest rate of chronic diseases and acute health problems in the world.
• A 2004 Study  done by the Environmental Working Group (EWG) analyzed blood samples of 10 babies before their birth.  Each baby on average had over 200 toxic chemicals already in their body.
• Cancer is the leading cause of death for children under fifteen.  Common childhood cancers: Leukemia, Lymphoma, bone and brain cancers.
• One third of all women and fifty percent of men will be diagnosed with cancer.
• In 2014 over 600,000 will die of cancer and close to 2 million will be diagnosed.

• Toxic chemicals in our blood triggers an inflammation response in our body that can cause serious health problems such as hormone imbalance and diseases like diabetes, obesity, heart and autoimmune problems.
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
• Our products are safe for you and the environment.
• Our unique ingredients like soapberry, seaweed, hickory bark extract, botanicals, butters, oils, antioxidants, green tea and essential oils make the difference.
• Our USDA certified organic products are minimum 95% organic content and no synthetic chemicals.
• Our NSF certified organic products are minimum 70% organic content and no harmful or harsh synthetic chemicals
• Our products are gluten-free, vegan, hypoallergenic, Non GMO, never tested on animals, contain no animal parts and safe for septic and grey water systems.
• Made in America!

column2: >Hi, I'd like to tell you why I started Saint Francis Organics.  It all began in my mid to late 30's when doctors said I needed to go on staten drugs and blood pressure lowering medication.   I had started gaining weight and even though I felt fine, my body was telling me something was wrong.   Both my parents died young: my mom of cancer and my dad of a heart attack.

column1: With my engineering background, I started to research and read everything I could on living a healthy lifestyle. I realized the standard American diet was loaded with harmful chemicals my body could not metabolize. I was killing myself slowly and didn't even realize it. I was eating the typical American diet of processed and fast foods that was loaded with sugar, the wrong fats, harmful preservatives and many other additives that my body was rejecting. I started eating healthier, whole foods and naturally raised meats. I found activities that raised my heart rate. Processed and fast food became the exception and not the rule.

I started looking for more natural household products and realized our choices were very limited. Everyday we use numerous personal care and cleaning products around our home that are filled with harmful and toxic chemicals. These chemicals enter our body through the air we breath and through our skin.  Saint Francis Organics products were developed to give people healthy alternatives free of harmful chemicals to use everyday in your bathroom, kitchen and laundry areas.

REAL Organic Products for a Healthy LifeWe only use natural ingredients.All our products are free of toxic chemicals and petrolium based ingredients.
The Power of Soap Berry

Saponin, the cleaning compound found in Soapberry, has been used for thousands of years by the Nepalese people  for cleaning and medicinal purposes.   Wild harvested in Nepal at the base of the Himalayan mountains, the organic fruit has become a major source of income and economic development for this poor region of the world.  We are happy to support the economic development in these rural areas of Nepal.  At Saint Francis Organics, we know Mother Nature always has natural ingredients that can take the place of synthetic chemicals. The cleaning and healing power of Saponin makes our hair, body, baby and cleaning household products unique. It does away with the harsh and toxic sulfate chemicals found in almost all household products today. Saponin soothes and nourishes irritated and sensitive skin and has been used by the Nepalese people to treat skin conditions like eczema, psoriasis and acne. You can trust Saint Francis Organics in all your household products to clean, soothe and heal your body. Why Reduce Chemical Interference in Our Body?
The U.S. has the highest rate of chronic diseases and acute health problems in the world.
A 2004 Study  done by the Environmental Working Group (EWG) analyzed blood samples of 10 babies before their birth.  Each baby on average had over 200 toxic chemicals already in their body.
Cancer is the leading cause of death for children under fifteen.  Common childhood cancers: Leukemia, Lymphoma, bone and brain cancers.
One third of all women and fifty percent of men will be diagnosed with cancer.
In 2014 over 600,000 will die of cancer and close to 2 million will be diagnosed.

Toxic chemicals in our blood triggers an inflammation response in our body that can cause serious health problems such as hormone imbalance and diseases like diabetes, obesity, heart and autoimmune problems.
Why Saint Francis Organics
Our products are safe for you and the environment.
Our unique ingredients like soapberry, seaweed, hickory bark extract, botanicals, butters, oils, antioxidants, green tea and essential oils make the difference.
Our USDA certified organic products are minimum 95% organic content and no synthetic chemicals.
Our NSF certified organic products are minimum 70% organic content and no harmful or harsh synthetic chemicals
Our products are gluten-free, vegan, hypoallergenic, Non GMO, never tested on animals, contain no animal parts and safe for septic and grey water systems.
Made in America!
Our StoryMeet the Saint Francis Organics team. We are Jared, Jon, Aaron & Jeanan...

Hi, I'd like to tell you why I started Saint Francis Organics.  It all began in my mid to late 30's when doctors said I needed to go on staten drugs and blood pressure lowering medication.   I had started gaining weight and even though I felt fine, my body was telling me something was wrong.   Both my parents died young: my mom of cancer and my dad of a heart attack.

With my engineering background, I started to research and read everything I could on living a healthy lifestyle. I realized the standard American diet was loaded with harmful chemicals my body could not metabolize. I was killing myself slowly and didn't even realize it. I was eating the typical American diet of processed and fast foods that was loaded with sugar, the wrong fats, harmful preservatives and many other additives that my body was rejecting. I started eating healthier, whole foods and naturally raised meats. I found activities that raised my heart rate. Processed and fast food became the exception and not the rule.

I started looking for more natural household products and realized our choices were very limited. Everyday we use numerous personal care and cleaning products around our home that are filled with harmful and toxic chemicals. These chemicals enter our body through the air we breath and through our skin.  Saint Francis Organics products were developed to give people healthy alternatives free of harmful chemicals to use everyday in your bathroom, kitchen and laundry areas.
How Will Funding Help Us?
Pay for annual USDA & NSF organic certifications.
Research & Development cost.
Launch New Organic NSF Personal Care products:  Body line (Ready), Hair Care (Ready),  Baby line (Ready), Facial Care (Under developement - 2nd quarter 2015).
Launch New Organic Cleaning products: Laundry and Dishwashing products:(Under developement -  2nd quarter 2015) and all-purpose Household Cleaner (Under developement - 2nd quarter 2015).
Help us tell the world about our Natural/Organic products.
Timeline
September 29th - We Launch Indiegogo campaign.
November 7th - Indiegogo campaign ends.
November 17th - Our USDA product Perks start shipping.
*November 30th - Estimated date of NSF certification.
*December 15th - Estimated shipping date for New NSF Perks.
*Refer to FAQ for more information about estimated dates.
Questions ? Please read our FAQ

*We expect to fulfill all of our crowdfunding orders in November and December.   Delays are unlikely, but possible. We promise to keep our backers aware of any delays that might occur in the certification process or manufacturing process.

Since the IndieGoGo Perk selection system does not allow for backers to select different scents, we will follow up with a survey letter after your order is recieved.  On the survey you will be asked to give us your 1st and 2nd choice of our wonderful essential oil scents.

IMAGINE
Close your eyes and imagine......  Imagine that you are once again nine years old.  School has just started
column2: you have new teachers and new friends.  You're taller than you were last year and you can run faster.  You have an arithmetic test tomorrow and you are dreading it.

column1: For the past few months, you have had a pain in the back of your head.  Sometimes, your vision is blurry.  Without warning, you become dizzy and often, the pain is so bad that you want to cry.  You have been afraid to tell your mom about the pain because you know that she will take you to the doctor.  One day, she noticed you crying and you told her what was bothering you.

After trips to more doctors and hospitals than you can count, and tests whose names you cannot pronounce or spell, your mom and dad come out of the doctor's office, crying.  They sit down with you and the doctor, and try to explain to you that you have cancer.  You have heard your parents talk about cancer.  But always, it was ""Joe died of cancer yesterday."" or ""Sally has cancer and she has four months to live.""  You don't really know what cancer is, but you know that it is bad, Very bad.

The doctor explains to you that there are medicines that you can take and treatments that you can be given to slow down or kill the cancer.  The doctor explains that you will be very sick.  You may lose your hair.  You will be tired and you will miss a lot of school. All of a sudden, you are ready for that arithmetic test and wish you could take it right now.  But you know that that is not going to happen. For the next six months, you visit the hospital on a regular basis.  All the doctors and nurses know you by name.  They stick needles in your arm to give you medicine that makes you sick.  They give you chemotherapy that makes you throw up and causes your hair to fall out.  You are nine and a half years old and you have no hair.  Many of your classmates laugh at you.  No one seems to understand that you are really sick.  You feel alone, even when you are surrounded by many people.

One day your parents talk to you about going to summer camp.  You're scared.  You don't want to go to a camp with people you don't know.  You don't want anybody else laughing at you.  Your doctor and parents have explained that if you fall or cut yourself, you might contract a secondary infection.  You have limits on what you can do, and you are afraid that you might get hurt and die. Your parents explain to you that this is a special camp for children who are sick, just like you.  There will be doctors and nurses there who you know.  You have never been to camp before but you have heard your friends talk about going to camp. You are afraid but you are also curious and the more you think about it, the more you want to go.

Finally, the day comes when you leave for camp.  Your parents take you to meet the bus, and the bus is full of kids your age and older.  Some of the kids are wearing hats and bandannas.  Some are wearing wigs too big for their head.  You sit down next to a boy two years older than you.  He sticks out his hand ""Hi, I'm Eric, I'm 11 years old and I'm a two-year bone marrow transplant survivor. What's your name?"" Conversations like this go on all over the bus.  Kids are talking about their doctors and nurses.  They are talking about other kids in their school.  You see your mom and dad hand a cooler to the bus driver, who puts the cooler under the bus.  You know that all your medicines are in that cooler.  Most of the kids have their own cooler.

The bus ride lasts five hours.  During that time, a 14 year old girl has become very sick.  The bus stops.  The girl gets off the bus and into a car that has been following the bus.  In the car are parents of other children on the bus.  The bus starts up and the car heads for the nearest hospital with the young girl.  You wonder how she's doing.  After a bus ride that seems to last forever, the bus slows down and pulls into a heavily wooded camp.  Already at the camp are 25 to 30 counselors, aged 18 to 30.  You look at them and can tell that they have been through what you are going through.  As you get off the bus, one of the counselors’ smiles, gives you a big hug, and welcomes you to Camp.  When everyone is off the bus your counselor has three other kids in tow and he leads you off to your cabin.  When you get there, you are surprised to see that the cabin has been decorated and that your name is on a bunk.  You are already feeling at home.  Maybe camp isn't so bad.

For the next five days, you have the opportunity to run, play, swim, eat, and interact with 70 to 100 other kids with cancer.  By the third day, no one is wearing a wig or hat.  You know most of the kids in camp.  You eat breakfast, lunch, and dinner together.  You take your medicines together.  You laugh and cry together. You walk by a group of older kids, who are talking about other kids.  You hear one ask about Larry, who was at camp last year, but is not here this year.  Someone else mentions that Larry died three months ago.  Larry was 13 years old.  You start to get scared.  The older group notices you.  They call you over, tell you not to worry and make you part of their group.  All of a sudden, you feel better about yourself.

Open your eyes.  This is not a dream.  You are at Rotary's Camp Florida (RCF).  RCF was founded to acquire, operate and maintain a year-round camp facility for children with special medical needs.  In addition to children with cancer, RCF hosts groups supporting children with Diabetes, Muscular Dystrophy, MS, and other debilitating diseases. Further, RCF makes its facilities available to special needs adult groups providing support for breast cancer survivors. An average camp is 80 to 110 campers per week, with virtually all of the summer weeks filled and most weekends the remainder of the year filled.

Support networks and life-long friendships are formed at RCF.  Children and counselors who are off treatment serve as role models and offer hope for those currently undergoing painful therapy.  For many of the children, this is their first and only chance to participate in normal life experiences during their struggle with cancer.

Second only to accidents, cancer is the number one cause of death of children age one through fifteen.  Only accidents take more lives from children.  In the past year, cancer occurred in approximately 7,800 children and took the lives of approximately 1,500.  One-third of these children died from leukemia.  However, in the past 40 years, the death rate from childhood cancers has dropped by almost 60 per cent.

Rotary's Camp Florida needs your help to get the new roof on our camp infirmary!  Camps use this facility to house medical professionals and staff while camp is in session. It operates as a clinic for any medical issues that arise at camp. Medication is stored there and the facility is completely handicapped accessible. Our infirmary has 9 hospital beds.
By contributing you can make a difference in the life of a child!!!

Please visit in regards to donations for the seizure dog.  Thanks Please visithttp://www.indiegogo.com/BabyMarcusSeizuredog/x/1319934 in regards to Kauffman donations for seizure dog

We are working on raising funds for little Marcus Lee.  He was born with a chromosome twenty duplication and one point three six deletion.  He has a heart valve that faces backwards and puts pressure on esophogus, two hernias, abnormal development of the brain so constant seizures, low muscle tone so has trouble holding up head and breathing.  He will need help with walking and mobility.  He is on 1.5 liters of oxygen while in hospital.  He will go home with five antiseizure meds, and over seven other meds.

He is tired of laying down and only fifteen months old so we are hoping to get him a little wheel chair for babies so he can be in a partial reclining position so not always laying down.  He has twenty one word vocabulary and is a fighter.  Socially he is age appropriate.  But motor skills at four to six months.

We are working hard to make sure he has the best quality life a baby can have under the circumstances.  He has seized so much that he has been in the hospital over twenty one times since he first started having seizures in January.
He laughs and enjoys stocking hats.  IF you cannot donate but like to send him a stocking hat you can mail it Marcus Lee Kauffman 10510 County Road 80, Carthage, MO  64836.

We just want to offer him the best life possible.  He was born 32 weeks gestation eight weeks early, had four drugs in his system and spent the first two weeks crying and in withdrawel.  We did not find out about him till he was thirty two days old.  He held up his hands and we could not walk away.

We finalized the adoption July 12, 2012 and he could not even make it to his own adoption as he was in the hospital.  Also he was not released till the day after his first birthday so he celebrated it a day late.  He was so weak his Dad had to help him attack his cake.  He has a GTube so cannot even eat it.  But he smashed it.

Marcus is amazing and worth fighting for.  He has the reddest hair I have seen on a baby in years.  The doctors at Mercy Childrens Hospital in KC Mo are doing all they can.  Our focus is to adapt our home to his special needs and offer him a life that he deserves.  He did not ask to be born let alone born to a drug addict mom.  He deserves all we can do.  HE is an amazing little boy with a beautiful smile and will to live.

<div>
Did you ever meet someone who is just himself, and sets everyone at ease?

That’s my husband, Stan Rosenthal, a man who is kind, genuine, hard, working from six years old until one day at 70 years old he just collapsed. Stan over the years has been a contributing, compassionate member of his community teaching others life and work skills so that they could earn a living. Now, at a time when he should be relaxing after all his working years, he finds himself in the fight for his life.
<ul>
• STAN NEEDS YOUR HELP.
• HE NEEDS FUNDS AND SUPPORT SO THAT HE CAN RECEIVE THE HELP THAT HIS HEART REQUIRES.
• STAN DESERVES AN IMPROVED HEART.

column3: > Seven years ago Stan had by-pass surgery and one of his arteries immediately shut down 6 months following the surgery. He has become progressively worsened over the years with more parts of his cardiovascular system shutting down until a couple of months ago he could barely breathe, and was in congestive heart failure.  As his wife, this was the most challenging and painful sights to bear.

column1: After being told numerous times over the last few years there was nothing more that could be done, Stan just pressed on continuing to help others, and work hard.  Within the last 2 months, Stan came across a doctor who has devoted time and energy to thoroughly investigate Stan’s heart failure and has come up with an innovative plan to improve his heart. This doctor is located on the other side of the country from where we live. There are numerous expenses involved which are not covered by insurance such as flying Stan cross-country, and temporary living expenses in California while recouping from surgery.

Stan is committed to improving and once again being a helping partner and wise listener within his neighborhood and community.  He is now on oxygen and walking daily to regain lost muscle strength in preparation for surgery.
Anything that you can do
whether it is contributing to the fund, networking or sharing this information with a friend, or just offering a prayer in support of Stan would be gratefully appreciated, welcomed, and valued.
Help Stan receive the improved heart he vastly deserves. There is a VERY, VERY, good chance this could happen with your help.
WE THANK YOU.

Short Summary

Ilan is an avid disc golfer that is now a software architect in Boston.  Howard is also a keen disc golfer, and is a patent attorney in Israel.  Howard holds a position on the board of the Israeli Disc Golf Association (IDGA).  Our work is entirely voluntary.

The sport has been struggling to stay alive for over 6 years, by setting up temporary courses once a month which is very difficult.  We cannot continue this way for much longer. The mobile equipment started to wear and the community of players doesn't have a home.
We have witnessed the sudden growth of the sport in other countries as soon as a permanent course is set up and recognize that is what is needed to finally accomplish growth.

It is exceedingly difficult to get land in Israel as well as funds for such venture.  Yet we now have finally got such land, pefectly suited to our needs and the park's, plus full wonderful cooperation of the National Parks Authority (whom have never done such project before).  The Authority have ample manpower (worth most of the cost of building the course) but no funds.
Helping fund this project will complement the contributions of local players who have been generous but have not covered all the costs of building.
This is truly a once in a lifetime opportunity, we doubt that there will be a better place at a better time for making the course.
At present we need to pay for building materials for the tees (throwing pads), about $2000 for 50 units. We plan to have two tees per target to allow multiple levels of play.

We also need to pay for 25 targets (baskets), that will cost about 600 each i.e. $15000 for 25 units. We need at least 18 targets for a full course, adding more will allow verstility of play and world class setup.
We have about half of that money collected.  Contributions of over $150 will entitle being on a plaque attached to a basket, acknlowledging the contribution.
We may have other expenses that we will have to cover, we will find ways to acknowledge contribution for those as well.

<div>The course will be built in an oasis in the desert and will be a great tourism and youth activity boost to the local area which has suffered much in recent regional wars.  Disc golf is a sport that mandates courtesy and respect as well as careful thought and planning, good educational tools for the region.
We have been conducting international chamipionships and draw on the experience of some immigrants and guests who have much experience abroad building such courses, such as Mr. James Beasley.
<div>
Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And thanks for reading this :)

","Short Summary

Ilan is an avid disc golfer that is now a software architect in Boston.  Howard is also a keen disc golfer, and is a patent attorney in Israel.  Howard holds a position on the board of the Israeli Disc Golf Association (IDGA).  Our work is entirely voluntary.

The sport has been struggling to stay alive for over 6 years, by setting up temporary courses once a month which is very difficult.  We cannot continue this way for much longer. The mobile equipment started to wear and the community of players doesn't have a home.
We have witnessed the sudden growth of the sport in other countries as soon as a permanent course is set up and recognize that is what is needed to finally accomplish growth.

It is exceedingly difficult to get land in Israel as well as funds for such venture.  Yet we now have finally got such land, pefectly suited to our needs and the park's, plus full wonderful cooperation of the National Parks Authority (whom have never done such project before).  The Authority have ample manpower (worth most of the cost of building the course) but no funds.
Helping fund this project will complement the contributions of local players who have been generous but have not covered all the costs of building.
This is truly a once in a lifetime opportunity, we doubt that there will be a better place at a better time for making the course.
What We Need & What You Get
At present we need to pay for building materials for the tees (throwing pads), about $2000 for 50 units. We plan to have two tees per target to allow multiple levels of play.

We also need to pay for 25 targets (baskets), that will cost about 600 each i.e. $15000 for 25 units. We need at least 18 targets for a full course, adding more will allow verstility of play and world class setup.
We have about half of that money collected.  Contributions of over $150 will entitle being on a plaque attached to a basket, acknlowledging the contribution.
We may have other expenses that we will have to cover, we will find ways to acknowledge contribution for those as well.
The Impact

The course will be built in an oasis in the desert and will be a great tourism and youth activity boost to the local area which has suffered much in recent regional wars.  Disc golf is a sport that mandates courtesy and respect as well as careful thought and planning, good educational tools for the region.
We have been conducting international chamipionships and draw on the experience of some immigrants and guests who have much experience abroad building such courses, such as Mr. James Beasley.
Other Ways You Can Help
